title_review: Delicious vegetarian food and friendly staff
review_preview: I was looking for a vegetarian restaurant in Madrid for my wife and I to take our meat eating cousins to.  The Reineta was five minutes from our hotel and seemed to have a varied menu.  I booked a table for four on-line was so...
review_full: I was looking for a vegetarian restaurant in Madrid for my wife and I to take our meat eating cousins to. The Reineta was five minutes from our hotel and seemed to have a varied menu. I booked a table for four on-line was so pleased with my choice. The restaurant was full on a Saturday evening and we were the first ones in at 9.00 p.m. The waitresses were really friendly and helpful. My wife and I (the vegetarians) thought the entire meal (starter, main and dessert) was delicious. We think our meat eating cousins eating veggie food for a change enjoyed theirs - they certainly cleared their plates. Other positives were a bright, clean restaurant and the most delicious carrot juice I've ever had!! If you are a vegetarian in Madrid try the Reineta I doubt you'll be disappointed; it's brilliant!

title_review: Good to taste the typical Asturian cuisine
review_preview: El Neru is located near Plaza del Sol, and offers typical Asturian cuisine. Since we booked a table of 15, rather than ordering à la carte, the staff suggested us their most typical plates, that brought in the center of the table for 3/4 people....
review_full: El Neru is located near Plaza del Sol, and offers typical Asturian cuisine. Since we booked a table of 15, rather than ordering à la carte, the staff suggested us their most typical plates, that brought in the center of the table for 3/4 people. We tasted the octopus a la gallega, the Spanish tortilla, a typical Astorian cheese and the famous jamon asado (that I recommend). Staff just spoke Spanish, so we had some communication difficulties. Quite expensive bill.

title_review: Overall good Asturian food, though not consistent
review_preview: Location - very central - 1 min walk fromPlaza Mayor, 3 mins from SOLAtmosphere- casual comfortable basement dining roomService - very very good and friendly .  I had the same server on two different evenings, and he had no problem with my...
review_full: Location - very central - 1 min walk from Plaza Mayor, 3 mins from SOL Atmosphere- casual comfortable basement dining room Service - very very good and friendly . I had the same server on two different evenings, and he had no problem with my broken Spanish. English does not seem to be widely spoken here , but it was no problem at all, and they had no attitude whatsoever with non Spanish speaking guests .  The food - some amazing , some so so. I first ate here on a fri evening , and the whole meal was amazing - the beans with clam were tasty, as was the Galician octopus . At the recommendation, the four of us shared a huge T bone steak - all of us thought it was tasty and prepared well. I went back to El Neru two nights later , and my experience was not as as good (maybe different chef) - the fish soup was bland , and the merluza cocida was disappointing - it was like some steamed merluza with a few chunks of potatoes (not like the stew I was expecting). The squid cooked in ink sauce was the best dish during my second time at el neru - the sauce was great . In spite of the foods not being all perfect, I’d still recommend this restaurant - be sure to order the beans with clams, and the octopus . Just stay away from the fish soup . The restaurant seemed not touristy at all , and the service was great .

title_review: Didn't find it a tourist trap at all
review_preview: We arrived before the kitchen opened and went away for a drink. When we got back, the bar was full and we worried we might have lost our chance, but that place is like the Tardis, a labyrinth of dining areas. We know all about...
review_full: We arrived before the kitchen opened and went away for a drink. When we got back, the bar was full and we worried we might have lost our chance, but that place is like the Tardis, a labyrinth of dining areas. We know all about tourist traps (we live in a Canarian tourist resort) and, contrary to some reviewers here, we didn't have that experience here. It certainly isn't a "posh" restaurant, but we had a pleasant meal where everything happened in an orderly way. We started with a bottle of cider to accompany the bread and allioli. The waiter went through the pouring routine - okay, that was touristy and he didn't do it for the Spanish family party at the next table, but no harm done. At least he cleaned up after himself :) . As it was an Asturian restaurant we passed on our favourite rabo de toro and plumped for the fabada. Specialities are always the ones to go for, and this was no exception - simple but tasty. The Rioja to accompany it was good too, and as expensive as always. I finished off with one of my favourite desserts. I don't know if you can still find the junket of my youth in the UK but in Spain cuajada is still going strong. The licor de hierbas asturiano offered with the coffee was very welcome.

review_preview: El Ñeru is a complete tourist trap. I was looking for one of the best Asturianos in Madrid and I mistakenly ran across this place due to the relatively good reviews it had received. Needless to say you can never underestimate the poor taste of...
review_full: El Ñeru is a complete tourist trap. I was looking for one of the best Asturianos in Madrid and I mistakenly ran across this place due to the relatively good reviews it had received. Needless to say you can never underestimate the poor taste of the general public.  1. BURNT FOOD - The cachopo I ordered was completely burnt  2. SERVICE CHARGE - They charge for “bread”- For me this is a complete turn off and just a way to gouge tourists for more money. (This meant bread and silverware) 3. FRAUDULENT ADVERTISING - The prices on the menu outside don’t correspond to the prices on the menu inside. I’m sure this has to be illegal but I guess it’s their way of enticing the unwary tourist into the wolf’s mouth. 4. RUDE MANAGER - The service was bad and the manager was completely rude. He didn’t help to resolve any of our concerns and instead responded to us with a very “macarra” attitude that one would expect to find in Benidorm or Magaluf rather than in the historic city center of Madrid In conclusion, don’t step foot in this place. There are plenty of Asturianos in Madrid where you will be able to get quality food and service from one of the nicest and most culturally rich places in Spain.

title_review: I am very familiar with flamenco
review_preview: I am very familiar with flamenco and this is one of the most authentic and intense shows I have seen. Flamenco is a lament, a wailing thumping beat to the clapping palms and stomping feet set to the haunting music of the flamenco guitar. It’s...
review_full: I am very familiar with flamenco and this is one of the most authentic and intense shows I have seen. Flamenco is a lament, a wailing thumping beat to the clapping palms and stomping feet set to the haunting music of the flamenco guitar. It’s not a family show.  It’s roots lie deep in the sad history of Spain and the Moors. I don’t always understand all the words but I understand the emotion which is key. The show at the Carboneras consists of exceptional dancers and interpreters of this beautiful art form.

review_preview: This venue is fantastic.  We couldn't visit Madrid and not see flamenco, so we booked this show and were absolutely mesmerized.  Like others, we booked this trip while on Sandemans walking tour.The venue is very intimate - probably about 100 or so patrons.  We,...
review_full: This venue is fantastic. We couldn't visit Madrid and not see flamenco, so we booked this show and were absolutely mesmerized. Like others, we booked this trip while on Sandemans walking tour. The venue is very intimate - probably about 100 or so patrons. We, a family of 4, sat at our own table and were served with a drink. Other options included dinner, but we chose against that. Nobody in the room was more than 20 feet or so away from the stage. There were 4 dancers who danced one at a time along with a couple of singers and a great guitarist. This was the first time I saw flamenco live and it got my heart racing. The energy they emit and the speed in which their feet move is incredible. I was looking for a good time, but this 1 hour show far exceeded my expectations.  I highly suggest that this be on everyone's itinerary.

review_preview: It is hard to live up to a Luxurious standard but this place meets every point to the "T."  looked for a restaurant with a Spanish flare and Spanish fish dishes, we had just left the Otto for drinks and went online on Trip Advisor...
review_full: It is hard to live up to a Luxurious standard but this place meets every point to the "T." looked for a restaurant with a Spanish flare and Spanish fish dishes, we had just left the Otto for drinks and went online on Trip Advisor to look for a good restaurant with our requirements. Walking in to this luxurious restaurant gave me the impression that I would need a Jacket to dine here, "Hola, habla usted Inglés?" We were greeted with a smile and was asked "do we have a reservation?" "no" we exclaimed and right away they knew we were American and was about to spend some "MONEY!" Lol Just kidding, they did seat us and we had some more drinks and some wine. The vibe was nice and the decor and colors in the restaurant just pooped, our last night in Madrid. As one person put it this felt "Intimate and elegant" experience, again the staff, our Maitre D was excellent she did not speak much English but she knew what we wanted and was there assisting others, the staff some spoke English and they also were excellent in every way. I saw a older gentleman leaving out and he had his coat hanging up, on the way out he stoped and a staff put his coat on for him, he never touched the coat, it just slid right on him like a super hero suite and he was out the door lol! The food was great the ambiance was awesome, party's or 2 and 5 and another group had a table with 12 at a mammoth table off to the side in its own room elevated up about two or three steps. After indulging in some more libations and desserts I decided to take a trip to the bathroom "Bano."   I shouldn't talk about using the restroom in this manor but "WOW!" I was blown away! OK moving on. This restaurant is like one of your best restaurants you go to in any Large City in the US or anywhere in the world, Excellent service and excellent food, we had some Ravioli stuffed with prawns, the Fish of the day and Martini Chocolate mousse. If you are ever in the Area of El Mentidero De la Villa please "Treat yourself don't cheat yourself." Check me out at >> M3aerialmediaworks.com

title_review: Excellent Food, Great Value, & Top Service
review_preview: Our best meal during a week + Spain trip was at Cava Maria.  Don't fall for other highly rated gourmet/artisan places in La Latina.  We tried another after Cava Maria because my daughter wanted to experience a new place.  Mistake.  Paid twice the euros for...
review_full: Our best meal during a week + Spain trip was at Cava Maria. Don't fall for other highly rated gourmet/artisan places in La Latina. We tried another after Cava Maria because my daughter wanted to experience a new place. Mistake. Paid twice the euros for half as much as would have gotten at Cava Maria. Sometimes, like when back at home, it pays to return to a place that's tried and true. That's what Cava Maria is. Indeed, when in Florence two years back, after discovering a fine steak restaurant by accident (strolled by), we returned for another meal during our few days in Florence. So, indulge in Cava Maria!

review_preview: We booked the "tapas and Flamenco" tour through our Free Walking tours - Sandemans. It was one of the best we did in Madrid. Our guide Yasmine was awesome! She managed a bilingual tour while keeping everyone engaged. We visited 2 bars before arriving to...
review_full: We booked the "tapas and Flamenco" tour through our Free Walking tours - Sandemans. It was one of the best we did in Madrid. Our guide Yasmine was awesome! She managed a bilingual tour while keeping everyone engaged. We visited 2 bars before arriving to Las Carboneras. There we were offered 2 drinks and 2 tapas, plus dessert, simply delicious! The show is done by true professionals. We had 3 bailadoras, one bailador, 2 cantadores and one guitarist. They were really passionate and their performance was simply outstanding. I'd do it again whenever I go back to Madrid. Booking is essential as it's a popular place with limited seating.

title_review: Marvelous Mojitos and Fun Fusion Entrées
review_preview: My husband and I ate here last night and had an enjoyable dining experience.  The restaurant has a glass enclosed patio area with tables and heaters so we were able to eat on the patio despite the chilly winter weather.  Our server was very attentive...
review_full: My husband and I ate here last night and had an enjoyable dining experience. The restaurant has a glass enclosed patio area with tables and heaters so we were able to eat on the patio despite the chilly winter weather. Our server was very attentive and efficient. We started with drinks. My husband ordered a glass of house red wine and I had an apple/ginger mojito that was phenomenal! It was sooooo good I ordered one more before the meal was over! My compliments to the bartender. These were some of the best Mojitos I have tasted in Madrid. The server brought us a delicious tomato soup to try that was on the house. Next we had bread and olive oil followed by a Burrata Cheese salad that was delicious. They serve artisan tacos so my husband got the Shrimp Tacos for an entrée and I got the Ropa Vieja (shredded meats) tacos with a quail egg on top . We decided to share and they were both tasty! A little plate of colorful gumdrops was served for dessert (however, there are desserts on the menu - we were just too full to order more food). The restaurant manager came out to greet us and check on us several times throughout the evening. On a side note, the bathroom was clean and on the main level of the restaurant - no stairs. The restaurant is located near a beautiful fountain /monument and near the museums so it is in a great location.

title_review: Nice restaurant and good for gluten free eating
review_preview: Tucked away underground, this restaurant is surprisingly light and airy. Staff greeted us nicely and despite not having booked ( I would recommend that you did) they helpfully found us a table. I am a coeliac, so finding somewhere that provides good quality, Spanish food...
review_full: Tucked away underground, this restaurant is surprisingly light and airy. Staff greeted us nicely and despite not having booked ( I would recommend that you did) they helpfully found us a table.  I am a coeliac, so finding somewhere that provides good quality, Spanish food is often difficult but they were very helpful. Whilst they did not have a separate menu, they pointed out what I could have and made special potatoes in a clean pan. NB if you don't already know this term, always ask if the chips are cooked in a clean pan, that way they won't be contaminated by other gluten containing items.  We ate spinach and mozzarella salad, followed by very tender pork chops with pears and onions which were delicious. Wine was good value and the service was great.  I would defiantly go here again if I return to Madrid.  Note, this is not the Cava Maria at Playa Mayor, but the same chain.

title_review: Punishment does not fit the "crime" - Not kid friendly!
review_preview: Let's start with the good.   The food was actually a very interesting mix of plates and we ordered a few appetizers as well as main courses.  Everything was very good, which I was impressed with given the eclectic nature of the food.  They have excellent...
review_full: Let's start with the good. The food was actually a very interesting mix of plates and we ordered a few appetizers as well as main courses. Everything was very good, which I was impressed with given the eclectic nature of the food. They have excellent ceviche and an excellent Reuben sandwhich for example (2 things I wouldn't expect a single restaurant to do well at the same time). The ambience is of course excellent being an Platea and having full view of the stage (there was a 1950s rock&roll band playing which was great). So why give it a 1 star. Well, unfortunately, all these great aspects were completely overshadowed by the fact that the restaurant's supervisors are completely ill-equipped to deal with a table with children (well-behaved children btw). We were 4 adults with 2 kids (2 and 5 years old). 1 of my kids unfortunately is very picky with food, so we asked the waitress if it was possible to serve a plate of white rice. The answer was no (strange, as they have at least 1 plate with sushi rice as the base). Then we asked if they had breaded chicken. The answer again was no. They did suggest another "chicken breast" option for kids, which I ordered knowing at least 1 of my kids would eat it. I then asked the waitress if it would be possible to get a tapa of breaded chicken from the other Platea bars downstairs (mind you, we are 4 adults and another child all ordering food and drinks from Canalla). She of course, cited the policy of the restaurant not to bring in outside food. I get it. Good policy on paper. But a policy one could bend for a 2 year old, if 4 adults are patronizing your restaurant and you refuse to make something as simple as a bowl of rice. We were told no, but my 2 year old still needed something more than the bread at the table. We pulled out some snacks from our baby backpack so he could eat something as well. That is when the harassment by the supervisory staff started. First, 2 women dressed in black suits with ear pieces (different than waiters) proceeded to stare us down for 20-30 minutes. Straight stare. I even tried to stare back in hopes they'd get the message that it was extremely uncomfortable, but they did not budge. They then approached the table and proceeded to lecture us that we couldn't have any outside food (let's remember, this is for a 2 year old... not like we brought our own wine or something). Ironically, at the same time they brought our food orders by, and the "chicken breast" was in fact breaded. I had literally asked if they had "breaded chicken" the first time and they said no (this is in Spanish btw, and there was definitely nothing lost in confusion, as my mother tongue is spanish). But at this point, we were already being lectured, with no real purpose of the outcome they wanted (did they want us to stand up and leave? no...). I asked to speak to the restaurant manager at that point, as they were rudely interrupting what should have been a nice lunch out watching some live music. The restaurant manager eventually came, as we were in the middle of our meal, and also proceeded to lecture without first asking what had happened (maybe good to get the customer's perspective too, before just going off on a customer based on the one-sided info from that staff)? Anyway, we finished our meal, and paid and on our way out asked for a Hoja de Reclamacion (a formal customer rights document establishments in Spain are forced to carry). That was the first time we heard a "sorry for how this was handled, and that we hope you return". Funny how the threat of a formal complaint changes attitudes. Anyway - I'd recommend the restaurant... but just not to anybody who has any toddlers who may not be interested in creative fusion dishes for more sophisticated pallates than a 2 year old.

title_review: A delicious meal in a very fun and creative environment!
review_preview: This restaurant is located in Platea, a whole complex dedicated to gastronomy, in a building that used to be Carlos III Movie Theater. The place is spectacular, a wonderful option for these incredibly hot summer days.We arrived around 3:30 pm and the kitchen of...
review_full: This restaurant is located in Platea, a whole complex dedicated to gastronomy, in a building that used to be Carlos III Movie Theater. The place is spectacular, a wonderful option for these incredibly hot summer days. We arrived around 3:30 pm and the kitchen of Canalla Bistro closes at 4:00 pm (they open again for at 8:30 pm for dinner), but they offered us a table and it worked out perfectly. We were surprised from the beginning, since the tables are located in what used to be the balcony of the theater. There is a large stage with its huge curtains in the front, and there was a flamenco dancer on what used to be the patio. After the flamenco show, a DJ was presented on the stage. The atmosphere was lively and fun. The food was fantastic! We enjoyed everything!. We had Croquetas al Pesto de Albahaca (croquettes with basil pesto), Buñuelo Cremoso y Crujiente de Bacalao con Emulsión de Miso (Creamy and Crunchy Cod Fritters), Gyozas de Cerdo Hoisin de Pimientos y Yuzu-Ponzu (Pork Pot Stickers with Hoisin Sauce), Pan al Vapor con Cochinita Pibil (Steamed Bun with Pork), Canelon de Aguacate con Bonito Marinado y Pico de Gallo (Avocado Caneloni with Bonito Flakes and Pico de Gallo)`and Causa Limeña de Corvina Ahumada (Fish Peruvian Causa). Original flavors and combinations, nicely plated, we wanted to lick the dishes!! For dessert, the Chocolate Cake was awesome. A base of chocolate cake, topped with chocolate mousse and a crispy chocolate cookie as thin as paper, with little chips of chocolate in every bite. A chocolate invasion in your mouth! Describing the food made me hungry. I think I will have go back to Canalla Bistro tonight!!

review_preview: I went to this restaurant as it was recommended by a food journalist in Madrid, and I left very dissatisfied.The ambiance is great, but the food was disappointed. I ordered several plates to try different items in the menu, and I could not find...
review_full: I went to this restaurant as it was recommended by a food journalist in Madrid, and I left very dissatisfied. The ambiance is great, but the food was disappointed.  I ordered several plates to try different items in the menu, and I could not find anything that I could qualify as decent. The plates that are Spanish - Latin - Asian fusion, are conceptually great, but taste is a total let down. The worst was the Calamar a la Romana that were not cooked properly and were served cold and soggy. Platea is a place to visit, but I would suggest to avoid this restaurant and try one of the tapas places downstairs. I am giving 2 stars because of the reservation experience, the location and the staff that was friendly.

title_review: A good Le Brunch but plenty of room for improvement
review_preview: We were a little confused when we arrived from the street entrance as we walked straight into the middle of the restaurant.  After standing awkwardly for a few minutes trying to get the attention of one of the 3 waitresses that were standing in the...
review_full: We were a little confused when we arrived from the street entrance as we walked straight into the middle of the restaurant. After standing awkwardly for a few minutes trying to get the attention of one of the 3 waitresses that were standing in the room we were finally told that they would be with us in a minute and we were shown around the buffet.The food on offer is a small selection of meats, tapas, paella, bread and some vegan options in one room. In another there are a few desserts and some beverages on offer.  The hotel restaurant has a very high class decor with an art deco feel, however service detail tends to lack. This should be pretty straight forward as the brunch is a self service buffet with a choice of 3 hot options available to order. We were constantly left with several empty plates on our table for up to 45 minutes. I could understand if the restaurant was busy but it was 35 percent capacity at best.  The food on offer was a nice standard and delicious however for a high end hotel, I find it hard to believe that there was no orange juice available when requested. Also the hotel seems to be very proud to offer their own "hot fudge" liquid chocolate made exclusively on site however some fresh fruit or churros would compliment it well as at 75% it is a little bitter on its own.  All in all the atmosphere is very relaxed and pleasant with a DJ playing in the corner but a better attention to detail from the staff working there would ensure a more enjoyable experience

title_review: Don’t hesitate to book this excellent restaurant.
review_preview: From the moment we walked in, the Maitre D’ José Manuel, was very friendly and attentive without being intrusive. Appetisers of cod in batter and ham croquetas were brought to the table with the menus and our drinks followed shortly after.Starters: Buñuelos de Calabacín...
review_full: From the moment we walked in, the Maitre D’ José Manuel, was very friendly and attentive without being intrusive. Appetisers of cod in batter and ham croquetas were brought to the table with the menus and our drinks followed shortly after. Starters: Buñuelos de Calabacín and Verduras de Parrilla. The zucchini was sweet and the tempura light and crispy. The vegetables were grilled to perfection and offered a wonderful variety of textures and flavours. Mains: Entrecote de Buey and Solomillitos Salteados con salsa de soja y Verduras. Both dishes were delicious; the soy sauce adding an oriental touch to the pork. There was more than ample food - we couldn’t manage a dessert.  A delicious home-made chocolate accompanied the bill. The restaurant is modern and clean with modern art adorning the walls. The service throughout was excellent.  The price is competitive and reasonable considering the freshness of the ingredients and the quality of the cooking.

title_review: Very Friendly Service and Delicious Traditional Food with a Gourmet Twist
review_preview: Today I had the pleasure of discovering this fairly new restaurant in the La Latina / Cava Baja area of Madrid which apparently opening in 2016. I regularly operate historical recreation tapas tours in Madrid, where I've resided for the past 28 years. I was...
review_full: Today I had the pleasure of discovering this fairly new restaurant in the La Latina / Cava Baja area of Madrid which apparently opening in 2016. I regularly operate historical recreation tapas tours in Madrid, where I've resided for the past 28 years. I was looking for a new supplier for my tours and was very pleased to come across CavaMaría. The service is very friendly and welcoming thanks to Maître José Manuel. In spite of being a basement, a lot of sunlight streams in through the many sidewalk level windows. The space is airy and pleasant and its historical building is well kept and offers a sense of tastefully renovated Old Madrid. I partook of a "menu of the day" on a Friday with dishes offering a sophisticated presentation and hearty portions. The food was excellent. The price-quality ratio, in my opinion, was superb. I'd highly recommend CavaMaria to both Madrid residents and visitors alike. Very welcoming ambience! ;-)

When we arrived back the restaurant had been seated with 5 tables total we asked for a section where there were several tables open so we could see the viewsshe said no you will sit here. We had made reservations two weeks earlier to be at this restaurant as we were traveling from the US. First time ever we were blantanly discriminated against for you see every table she sat beyond us was a local. We were not and we were treated so. If you are from Madrid this might be a place for you if you are traveling from elsewhere there are so many incredible restaurants in this city with incredible food, good wine and welcoming service. Hard pass for us. Chef your food didn’t stand out your rude front desk person did.

From a couple of plates we tried I can point out only Parpatana de Atun as something interesting thats worth of trying.  I think next time I'll try Platea food flor instead Canella.

review_preview: After enjoying shopping at Salamanca, I went to sinatra ya with my friends. It was the second day after they opened it. There were lots of unusual dishes which I’ve never seen. Everything was curious :D We had a shabu-shabu hot pot with Kobe beef....

Everything was curious :D We had a shabu-shabu hot pot with Kobe beef. It was soooo delicious!! Best beef I’ve ever had. Dip in a thick & creamy sesame sauce or Ponzu and actually beef melts in your mouth! Both Sukiyaki and Shabu shabu hot pot accompanied with various kinds of vegetables and noodles which is also enjoyable. It’s perfect for the current season! I would come back to try Wagyu Sushi next time. Highly recommended.

title_review: A welcoming oasis of good food and service in the madness of La Latina.
review_preview: Visting the Rastro market on a Sunday in Madrid is an experience, but it is crowded. Five of us walked around the area trying to find space to sit down and eat. It was virtually impossible, then we found Cava Maria, on a street close...
review_full: Visting the Rastro market on a Sunday in Madrid is an experience, but it is crowded. Five of us walked around the area trying to find space to sit down and eat. It was virtually impossible, then we found Cava Maria, on a street close to La Latina metro. If anyone ever wants a definition of "dropping lucky" then finding Cava Maria is it. The restaurant is fairly new so may it will get busier as more people start to know about it. Located on a corner, the tables are downstairs and we ate A La Carte although I understand a buffet was available. Between us we had paella dishes, tapas, calamari and a steak, assisted by good Englsih and very warm service to choose our food. Cava (not surprisingly with the name) and beer also available. This makes the rstauarant sound fairly standard, but it's not. The qualtiy of everything, service, drink, food, was top notch in every sense. It was the best eating experience we had in Madrid and is a place that should be sought out.

title_review: The worst Lunch I have ever had in Madrid.
review_preview: Booked a table for an early Saturday Lunch at 14:00for three people.Service could not be faulted but the food! What a disaster...We shared a tempura of vegetables as a starter which was billed as something slightly different. It was ...the batter was spicey...
review_full: Booked a table for an early Saturday Lunch at 14:00for three people. Service could not be faulted but the food! What a disaster... We shared a tempura of vegetables as a starter which was billed as something slightly different. It was ...the batter was spicey as promised but we didn’t expect it to be wet and soggy. It was like eating raw flour paste with chilli powder...totally inedible. I had tuna tartar. The sauce was so hot that it could have been plastic that I was eating. It was very like bottled sweet chilli sauce that was used. Zero taste of fish. It came on a bed or watery overlooked rice. I didn’t eat any of it ... If you want to eat in Platea stay downstairs. There is some great food. Don’t bother walking upstairs it will cost you five times more and you, like me, will be disappointed .. Bob ..resident of Madrid for 15 years

I don’t eat onion, garlic and spicy, so it wasn’t possible to make something without this ingredients and I was obliged to have a burger. To start we had a croqueta de pollo and it was terrible, there was a chicken bone inside, so I risked my life and the only thing at the end was that I didn’t pay for it, without any excuse! It never happened to me before! The hamburger was boring, the fries very normal, nothing special, more bread than meat. My husband had the pork ribs, undercooked and only tasting of onion! I won’t go there anymore!!!

review_preview: We arrived around 8 and the waiter seemed surprised we were there. Casual restaurant and the waiters were the bartenders. It seemed more like a cocktail bar than a restaurant. The food was good, decent portions, and One of the party had a vodka martini...
review_full: We arrived around 8 and the waiter seemed surprised we were there. Casual restaurant and the waiters were the bartenders. It seemed more like a cocktail bar than a restaurant. The food was good, decent portions, and One of the party had a vodka martini and asked for Grey Goose. The bartender ran out and mixed in some Absolute. Interesting moment but didn't take away from the experience. They gave us a free bowl of "salmorejo." This is one of the places in Spain that translated "ternero" to veal and served lamb. The corn tortillas were terrible. Ordered a mushroom dish with an egg which was not memorable. It wasn't Mexican (we are Mexican), but it was a nice experience.

review_preview: The food is more "fusion" and more Spanish than Mexican. This is not the place to get Huevos Rancheros, but I had  great meal with eggs and Iberian ham that was obviously inspired by the traditional Mexican meal.  They have a nice wine menu with...
review_full: The food is more "fusion" and more Spanish than Mexican. This is not the place to get Huevos Rancheros, but I had great meal with eggs and Iberian ham that was obviously inspired by the traditional Mexican meal. They have a nice wine menu with very reasonable prices. Our server was extremely helpful and nice and spoke English quite well. We sat in a little enclosed outdoor area on the sidewalk that they said they opened up when the weather warmed up. We loved Comala and we will definitely come back if/when we visit Madrid again. It's right around the corner from the Prado, so do yourself a favor and go eat at Comala after (or before) you visit the museum

Delicious wines, a good selection of cocktails and Frank Sinatra singing discreetly in the background. We'll go back again that's for sure!

title_review: Sadly - not nearly as good as Canalla Bistro in Valencia
review_preview: The good: Having been just recently to Canalla Bistro in Valencia where I was blown away by the creative and very tasteful menu I had high hopes for the visit to the restaurant bearing the same name by the same chef. The food was good...
review_full: The good: Having been just recently to Canalla Bistro in Valencia where I was blown away by the creative and very tasteful menu I had high hopes for the visit to the restaurant bearing the same name by the same chef. The food was good but in no way as good and fresh as in Valencia (don't dump the sauce over the tempura veggetable - it was a mush!). It was just lacking that Wow factor. We were surprised to hear that none of the staff, who was very friendly and attended to all our needs during our visit, ever had visited the local in Valencia. It might be a good idea so they see what they’re up against! As it was our wedding anniversary we received a complimentary glass of champagne, which I thought was a nice touch.  The bad: The restaurant was closed from the 1st to the 30th of August (welcome to Spain). The only option to make a reservation was online. A couple of days later I wanted to move the reservation by half an hour. Sadly the phone number provided went straight to voice mail reminding me that the place was closed, even though by now it was the 31st of August. I wrote a message on their FB page hoping someone would read it and called the restaurant in Valencia to see if they can reach someone in Madrid to let them know that their phone line isn’t working but they supposedly had no way of contacting Madrid – really? I called again on the 1st of September just to get the same message. I eventually got a reply on my FB post that there was a technical error and someone would call me. No one called me. I wrote another post and I got another message calling me Oscar (why, I have no idea) and saying that they will get to the bottom of the issue. Over the course of three days I had not been able to change my reservation. Eventually we just walked in 30 minutes after the original reservation time. The reason why I'm writing this in detail as a bad experience is that the restaurant itself says that tables will only be hold for 15 minutes after reservation time! I don’t care how many Michelin stars or Repsol Suns a chef won, for me as a customer it’s the whole package that counts and for a restaurant where I don’t leave under 150 EUR for two people I expect the service to be outstanding from beginning to the end of the experience. The conclusion: Canalla Bistro Madrid can’t compete with its sister restaurant in Valencia. The food is ok but not as fresh and innovative as expected. The staff at the restaurant is nevertheless friendly and accommodating. It might help though to send them to Valencia to see how it is done and to let them know what they are up against. Due to a technical issue (as their statement) with their phone number during three days it was a very annoying and at the end impossible experience to simply change a reservation. It’s sadly no thumbs up, the food in the food court downstairs of Platea is definitely better.

title_review: A great destination for lunch or dinner.
review_preview: Having visited the better market food stall in Madrid the day before, my wife and I ventured North to Platea, a large shopping mall a short walk north of El Retiro Park. Brits may not expect to find a good food service place inside a...
review_full: Having visited the better market food stall in Madrid the day before, my wife and I ventured North to Platea, a large shopping mall a short walk north of El Retiro Park. Brits may not expect to find a good food service place inside a mall but, nevertheless, there is one here. The main area at ground floor level is ringed by small food outlets and small bars where the locals come for lunch and dinner. We did as advised by our very friendly hotel staff and rolled up at lunchtime for some very agreeable tapas and 'a glass of'. Our waitress was very accommodating with all our questions and she suggested we return for dinner that (Saturday) night as there is a show. So we did exactly that but we booked a table in the rather posher restaurant on the first floor and overlooking the performance area. What a good decision that was ! I grant you - a Saturday evening show in a shopping mall doesn't normally fill a customer will excitement or expectation of a good time but a good time was had, and no mistake. The big jazz band was completely to our taste and the fit half-naked Spanish bloke hanging and swinging from the ceiling seemed to do it for my wife !! Fabulous food, good service - even though the restaurant was full - and highly recommendable. After dinner we went up one more level to El Palco cocktail bar !!

The choice of sweets is that I've found sublime. The best of all the menu. Cakes elegant, soft and sweet. Service informal but professional. Prices a little bit higher than average.

review_full: My favorite meal in Madrid. We were staying at the Ritz right next door and did not feel like going far for dinner after a day of sightseeing so we popped in to Comala. We started with soft taco with Spain stew, very spicy and flavorful. For mains my wife had the Beef tenderloin grilled (served Tataki mode), with Mole Poblano and Tamalito sweet corn with raisins and I had the Iberian Mexican meatballs in sauce with saffron couscous and roasted sweet potatoes, each were excellent. For dessert we each had Quemada Passion Fruit Mousse with Wild Berries  Passion Fruit Creme Brulee With Wild Berries, a little to tart for my wife, I liked it a lot. Very good Sangria and coffee also. The food IS spicy and has a nice kick to it.

Obviously we shall not return.

title_review: EXCELLENT!!!! BEST DINNER OF MY LIFE!
review_preview: Went here as a plan B when a dinner at the principe cafe was cancelled. We were a group of 16 on a familirization trip to Madrid. The manangement is excellent, he himself came to the table about 20 times to assist us in anything...
review_full: Went here as a plan B when a dinner at the principe cafe was cancelled. We were a group of 16 on a familirization trip to Madrid. The manangement is excellent, he himself came to the table about 20 times to assist us in anything we needed and make sure everyone was comfortable. The reservation was last minute about 1 hour before and he was so great! The dinner was I believe 55 euro per person. I could not stress enough how lovely and great this dinner was. He served about 8 different appetizers ( salad, chicken, tacos,omelets everything) I believe thats what tapas is for, but plates just kept coming and coming. For the entree we had the famous spanish paella which was delicious and for dessert we had flan and also the option of granizado. The flamenco show was beautiful, the ladies showed so much expression with their dance, body and faces it was just amazing. The dinner also included wine sangria beer, water and juices. This place is fantastic, it was one of the highlights of my trip to madrid!

review_preview: This venue came highly recommended by a friend of a friend who hails from Madrid, and when it comes to food knows what he's talking about.We arrived Saturday evening about 8.30pm which is early for the locals to have dinner, but we were hungry...
review_full: This venue came highly recommended by a friend of a friend who hails from Madrid, and when it comes to food knows what he's talking about. We arrived Saturday evening about 8.30pm which is early for the locals to have dinner, but we were hungry and to begin with were the only ones in the restaurant. After we had been seated the place filled up within half an hour, and there was a healthy buzz to the place with all the table upstairs having been taken. We were too lazy to work out the English for everything on the menu so went for the Degustaçian de Tapas which was a very reasonably priced €30 for the two of us. We also ordered some patatas fritas which were sensational. As the tapas began arriving we knew we were in for a treat as each one of them was sensational – Japanese rolls with a thick sticky soy sauce, salmon with gravadlax, a tangy salad and tuna. These were followed by chilli con carne, langoustines, mini-hamburgers, dumplings and a wonderfully meaty ‘bombe’. Each was a taste sensation, lovingly prepared and wonderfully executed. The finale – a gooey chocolate cake presented in a pool of custard and cheesecake rounded off the most satisfying meal of the weekend. The staff were great, indeed I can’t find anything to fault about this extraordinary restaurant - superb value for money as well as out of this world cuisine. Not to be missed.

review_preview: Great food and atmosphere. Get there early if you want to get a table, as they do not take telephone bookings. When you get there you will be asked for your name and how many people you want for the table, but OJO - everyone...
review_full: Great food and atmosphere. Get there early if you want to get a table, as they do not take telephone bookings. When you get there you will be asked for your name and how many people you want for the table, but OJO - everyone has to be there when you book the table. I would recommend the jabalí (wild boar), which is incredibly tender (my favourite), the bombas de patata (mashed potato) and the tempura (fried vegetables). It gets hot in the restaurant if you sit round the back because of the lights, so if possible it's better to sit near the front. The service isn't great - expect to be waiting around a lot for the bill, but this is to be expected in restaurants in Madrid, and Spain in general.

review_preview: We had the Degustacian de Tapas between two of us for €30 total which was fantastic value for money considering the amount and quality of food we received. We didn't understand what was on the menu so what we received was all guesswork. We were...
review_full: We had the Degustacian de Tapas between two of us for €30 total which was fantastic value for money considering the amount and quality of food we received. We didn't understand what was on the menu so what we received was all guesswork. We were first presented with cold tapas which consisted of sushi, a delicious salad, gravalax and potted tuna. The hot tapas then followed with mini burgers, bbq'd prawns, dumplings and the recommended bomba which is a deep fried potato filled with a delicious meaty sauce. We also got two desserts with the deal. These were an amazing cheesecake and a rich hot chocolate pudding. The decor was fantastic as was the service. Overall we would definitely recommend a visit, especially if you're looking for an exciting twist on Spanish tapas!

review_preview: First thing's first - I would highly recommend visiting La Musa. My girlfriend and I went for dinner recently (recommendation - book in advance!) and enjoyed everything about La Musa.The food is great, with some really impressive and unusual small dishes - La Bomba...
review_full: First thing's first - I would highly recommend visiting La Musa. My girlfriend and I went for dinner recently (recommendation - book in advance!) and enjoyed everything about La Musa. The food is great, with some really impressive and unusual small dishes - La Bomba and the wild boar dishes being worthy of mention - including for desserts. There are plenty of wines to choose from, and reasonably priced the are too - we had a lovely Malbec for around 16 euros. The decor is very cool - we were downstairs and the decorations on the walls, the tables and chairs, all have quite a trendy but unpretentious feel to them. The atmosphere is nice, too - it's clearly a popular choice for dinner on Saturday nights - we had to settle for an 'early' 9pm slot - with good music playing, not too loud, and a nice crowd in there. Finally, the service was really good. As with the best restaurant staff, our waitress was friendly and attentive but not overbearing. Her recommended dishes, too, were gratefully received. To reiterate - La Musa comes highly recommended. Book in advance to avoid disappointment.

title_review: Best lunch I had in Madrid
review_preview: Stopped here for lunch after sightseeing in Opera.  While it was one of the more expensive lunches I had (11 euros), it was worth every penny.  I had a salad with langoustines and avocado for my first course, and a crispy spring roll filled with...
review_full: Stopped here for lunch after sightseeing in Opera. While it was one of the more expensive lunches I had (11 euros), it was worth every penny. I had a salad with langoustines and avocado for my first course, and a crispy spring roll filled with duck confit and green apple, served with mashed sweet potatoes and a round of foie gras mousse for my second course. There was a choice of coffee or dessert, and I chose a very light and delicious puff pastry-type cake filled with sweetened cream and fresh strawberries. The meal also included a drink (I had tinto de verano - red wine with sparkling lemonade) and bread. Overall, it was a fantastic experience, and if I ever find myself in Madrid again La Musa Latina will definitely be on my itinerary. The atmosphere was modern and clean, and they had a very cool looking bathroom area downstairs.

title_review: Very nice dinner with our team

review_full: Been there with a team of 8 to have an award dinner for excellent performance throughout last year. Restaurant was chosen by our team locally and we got a reserved space at the back of the restaurant where we were a bit for ourselves. Service was great, the choice of appetizers very nice and we ordered even some main courses to share as tapas as we could not make up our minds as to what to have given the excellent choice. review_preview: I was recommended Las Caboneras by a Uruguayan friend of mine whose boyfriend is a professional flamenco dancer. When she knew I was going to Madrid she said I had to go there to see 'proper' flamenco.  We booked online in advance and booked show...
review_full: I was recommended Las Caboneras by a Uruguayan friend of mine whose boyfriend is a professional flamenco dancer. When she knew I was going to Madrid she said I had to go there to see 'proper' flamenco. We booked online in advance and booked show and dinner €70.50 per head.  Our table was at the front, in fact less than a metre from the stage, so we were able to see all the footwork of the dancers.  The evening began with a huge dish of olives followed by the set meal - 'tapas' starters, paella and chocolate dessert. All alcohol was free - we started with sangria then two of us went onto red wine whilst our friend stuck with sangria.  The starters were typically Spanish. Croquettes (some chicken, some fish),tuna salad, a plate of cold meats (chorizo, Serrano ham, etc), tortilla, cheeses and bread. Calling them tapas is an insult, the helpings were very generous indeed.  The main course was paella, two of us had traditional paella, with prawns and chicken, another person had the vegetable option. Again delicious. The chocolate cake was scrumptious, definitely home made. Now to the entertainment - the flamenco performers change regularly so there is no danger of them being jaded or predictable. The group performed non stop for a full hour. The energy, commitment and passion has to be seen to be believed. Whatever your thoughts on flamenco dancing, go and experience it.

review_preview: One of the main things that I wanted to do in Madrid was to see a Flamenco show.  I have always found the dance to be fascinating and full of passion.  I'm not sure if my three companions were quite as thrilled to go, but...
review_full: One of the main things that I wanted to do in Madrid was to see a Flamenco show. I have always found the dance to be fascinating and full of passion. I'm not sure if my three companions were quite as thrilled to go, but after they admitted that they loved it. This is a dinner show, we were a tour group so we didn't have choices from a menu. We were served Paella, some vegetables and a dessert. The show started about an hour after. The place is rather small, which gives everyone a good view. There is a raised stage, where the performers are. I also love Spanish guitar, and we were fortunate to hear some of that as well. But the Dancers, when they walked out in the colorful costumes, the women with the slick backed buns and the flowers in their hair, with beautiful shawls and fans. The men in the tight black pants, it gave me goosebumps. I have waited so long to be able to see this. The dancing was breath taking, the passion and the speed. Their feet never still. I absolutely loved it. I would not hesitate to recommend to everyone to see a Flamenco show while in Spain. It was most enjoyable, entertaining, and the talent was awesome. As I said, my three male companions also enjoyed it very much..

The Restaurant (and probably the hotel) is chic and obviously exclusive, furnished to a high standard and quality and had a "colonial" feel (probably the antique furnishings, high ceilings, windows and doors). Very nice food, typically Spanish, served in a professional manner, accompanied by a very good wine. YOUnique does not come cheap, but it was not as expensive as my first impressions might have led me to believe. A "class above" restaurant that probably has yet to be discovered, going by the number of reviews to date on Tripadvisor.

The menu very modern and different, we struggled to choose, but started to order and were stopped by the waiter when he felt we had ordered plenty ... if we were still hungry he'd bring us more!! Thank god he did because after the gorgeous aubergine humous, calamari, delicious mixed croquettes and variety of bbq hanging kebabs, 3 large beers and 3 large red wines, we were very happy, very stuffed and only €40 lighter ... what a bargain and what a find!! If we went back to Madrid, my trip would not be complete without a re-visit!!

title_review: Must visit for lunch in Madrid
review_preview: Bigger, younger sister of La Musa in the Malasana district. Located in a cute square in the old town district of the city - outside seating if the weather is nice allows you to really soak up the European culture. Inside is great and very...
review_full: Bigger, younger sister of La Musa in the Malasana district. Located in a cute square in the old town district of the city - outside seating if the weather is nice allows you to really soak up the European culture. Inside is great and very nicely decorated. Chic, on trend and a great spot to spend an hour or two. Service is wonderful and all the staff are great and speak at least English (as well as Spanish) and some are fluent in French and German as well. The food is incredible and great for a lunch or lighter dinner. The style is tapas, but not traditional in the sense of what you will find everywhere else in Spain. This is more of a modern twist and it is delicious. We particularly loved the Bomba (meat and cheese stuffed potato balls - amazing), the langoustine and avocado tempura (so good) and the jamon croqutte - just creamy, deliciousness - we didn't have anything we didn't love. I would highly recommend eating here - oh and free wifi for us tourists :)

review_full: This is probably one of the best places that I've eaten in Madrid. I loved their mozzarella sticks and their fries. The service is very laid back so do not expect your waitress to check up on you often. The one thing that was very interesting about the service that Ive never experienced before is that when your food arrives the waitress asks you to check if the meat is cooked to your preference before she walks away.  This place is good value for your money and I would definitely return again!

review_preview: We had been to Madrid before and seen flamenco so I thought I knew what to expect.  I was completely floored though by our experience here.  We did the paella dinner followed by the flamenco show and I honestly kept my expectations very low because...
review_full: We had been to Madrid before and seen flamenco so I thought I knew what to expect. I was completely floored though by our experience here. We did the paella dinner followed by the flamenco show and I honestly kept my expectations very low because I just figured that the food would be rubbish - I could not have been more wrong! The meal started off with a delicious salad followed by what, to me, was an endless supply of tapas! I was expecting the salad, but the tapas was a nice surprise of croquettes, cheese, Iberic jamon, other meats and a few other delicacies. I was already full at this point, but then they brought out the paella which was to die for. If that was not enough, they offered two dessert choices: what appeared to be a carrot cake and chocolate cake, both of which were delicious. That was just the food!!! I was already in gay spirits because the food was so good, but then the four flamenco dancers and the band took the stage. Those dancers had so much passion and vigor that I too wanted to jump up and start dancing! Each one did about fifteen minutes making the show a little over an hour which was the perfect amount of time. Whether people consider this place a "tourist trap" or not, who cares?? I highly recommend you make the time to visit this place as it is something you will never forget.

title_review: An inexpensive way to enjoy a flamenco show

We wanted to see flamenco but did not want to spend close to 100 euros each at one of the more famous establishments. The cost was 23 euros each, and for that we got a jug of sangria for 3, some tapas and seats at the back of the room. We had a good view of the stage. The show was enjoyable, three female dancers, one male, and a good band. We felt we got our money's worth. This place is just behind the Mercado San Miguel so when our show ended at 10:30 pm we went to the Mercado for coffees, tapas and people watching.

title_review: Fun Place, Good Food, Good Prices
review_preview: When we want something quick and casual we often come here.  This tapas place is located in one of my favorite plazas. You can sit outside or inside.  Service is pretty good. Most understand english very well, and the prices are also very reasonable.  We've...
review_full: When we want something quick and casual we often come here. This tapas place is located in one of my favorite plazas. You can sit outside or inside. Service is pretty good. Most understand english very well, and the prices are also very reasonable. We've been several times now and everything we've had so far has been good to very good. The tapas here are unusual (if you want traditional Spanish tapas this is not your place). The makipans are truly original (they are like sushi rolls, but made with bread), though they are my least favorite. We love the la bomba, the empanadillas japonese (gyozas), the fried tomato, and the chocolatisimo. Lots more items still to try.

review_full: I have been visiting La Musa several times in 2011-2012 and now again in January 2014. Everyone I took to this restaurant loved it. It is one of my favourite restaurants in Madrid because of its special, original and high-quality tapas, its location and its friendly staff. I would definitely recommend the guacamole (to be smashed by you) and la bomba (for potato lovers). They now also have sort of "maki sushi" but with sandwiches instead of rice, which I did not really like. The location is amazing and in summer (or whenever it is sunny :-)) it is very nice to sit outside on this square. The bars around it are great for drinks after dinner.

I don't even think they had the usual jamon and patatas bravas on the menu. So - it was tapas but with a pretty significant difference. They even have a guacamole you mash yourself on the menu. We ended up eating there twice and having a varied number of their tapas and were satisfied both times.  The weather was too cold to sit outside - but the interior was nice and the wait staff dressed up for Halloween on October 31st. It is a pretty young crowd but I enjoyed it - even if I did feel like everyone's mother....

review_preview: We decided to go the Las Carboneras after reading reports on its flamenco and food quality. When we booked, the staff spoke great English, they were very helpful in explaining prices and options to us. When we turned up on the night, we were early...
review_full: We decided to go the Las Carboneras after reading reports on its flamenco and food quality. When we booked, the staff spoke great English, they were very helpful in explaining prices and options to us. When we turned up on the night, we were early and were told we could stay or come back in an hour as the first show was about to start and they didnt want us to have a spoilt evening by seeing the show too early. The stsaff said they would save us a great table as a result, and they definitely did. We were seated at a table right in front of the stage. The menu had several options, which when we ordered, were all very tasty, Good sized portions and great flavours. It was all you could drink on any drinks too which was a massive bonus.  The show itself was brilliant lasting around an hour. The energy was fabulous and the atmosphere superb. A highly recommended show and dinner. Yes its pricey at 60 euros per person, but for the chance to see good flamenco and have a really good 3 course meal, we were happy to pay it

review_preview: The bill was 108 Euros (~ $149) for two. This inlcuded a bottle of wine "discounted" to 14 Euros (~ $19), and a plate of Spanish cold cuts, 28 Euros (~ $39). That means a relatively short show was 66 Euros (~ $91). Most importantly,...
review_full: The bill was 108 Euros (~ $149) for two. This inlcuded a bottle of wine "discounted" to 14 Euros (~ $19), and a plate of Spanish cold cuts, 28 Euros (~ $39). That means a relatively short show was 66 Euros (~ $91). Most importantly, I didn't see any Spaniards among the guests and some locals told me the place was "commericialized". Apparently the natives go to more genuine places where the prices are much lower. Not one of them recommended las Carboneras. I was left with the impresison that las Carboneras is a typical tourist trap. I know enough Spanish and about Spanish flamenco to notice that the performers were "ad libbing" as they went along. At one point one of the singers kept singing "meow, meow, meow" and the performers had a hard time hiding their smirks - probably thinking how naive the toruists must be to think this was serious art. My understanding is that the restaurant hires different groups all the time and supposedly on some days you get better quality than on others.

title_review: a shame madrid is far away
review_preview: We were staying in Madrid for a few days and found this tapas restaurant, not far from the royal palace. Tapas places are wall to wall in this area, but we loved this one, which was a bit different. You can sit outside in a...
review_full: We were staying in Madrid for a few days and found this tapas restaurant, not far from the royal palace. Tapas places are wall to wall in this area, but we loved this one, which was a bit different. You can sit outside in a pretty little square, but the decoration inside is very cool and modern - it has an amazing 'living wall' of moss and fern, and there's a Japanese feel to many of its dishes. I don't eat meat, so they customised their tapas for two for E30 with fish. This included the best tempura squid I've ever had. We liked it so much we went a second time and had lovely food again - including "Chocolatissimo", a small but perfectly formed dessert with a really intense chocolate hit. The staff were also really friendly and we just wish it was closer so we could go more often. Definitely recommended if you're visiting Madrid.

review_preview: we visited La Musa Latina twice during our stay in Madrid, what a wonderful place! the place has such a trendy and laid back vibe but delivers food of real quality! the first night we arrived before 8 o clock to find that the kitchen...
review_full: we visited La Musa Latina twice during our stay in Madrid, what a wonderful place! the place has such a trendy and laid back vibe but delivers food of real quality! the first night we arrived before 8 o clock to find that the kitchen wasnt open until 8, but not to worry we could choose something from the snacks menu. we chose deepfried prawns with avocado and some chili con carne and nachos for the table along with hummus and crispy pitta. the whole meal was exceptional and really good value, in particular the chili con carne which was made with tender meat pieces as opposed to the tradional way of making it with ground mince meat. the second night we went back for some more casual tapas and ordered the nachos (with guacomole you pound up yourself to your own taste-fun!) along with a barbequed mix platter which was barbequed pork, beef, chicken and prawns! really delicious food and friendly service, if a little slow at times! the chocolatissimo desert was also fab! really good value place with a brilliant atmosphere, we will definitely be back!

title_review: Tasty, Trendy, Nice Ambiance, Boutique Restaurant
review_preview: We went to the Arab quarter and looked for La Musa Latina because it was recommended in Rick Steve's book. This is a lively trendy, elegant vibe restaurant. It has tables outside facing “Plaza de la Paja” but we decided to eat inside. This restaurant...
review_full: We went to the Arab quarter and looked for La Musa Latina because it was recommended in Rick Steve's book. This is a lively trendy, elegant vibe restaurant. It has tables outside facing “Plaza de la Paja” but we decided to eat inside. This restaurant had great atmosphere and lovely well decorated interior. Since we got a bit earlier, it was quiet but soon the atmosphere became lively with a trendy scene as people started to fill the restaurant. Then, we remembered that people in Spain eat later than in the US. It has a creative menu of unique salads and tapas. The tapas are a bit different than the traditional tapas but with tasty inventive variations. The menu is written in the form of a newspaper, with each 'article' giving different selections of food. We tried grilled garlic shrimp and “bomba” (a sliced potato filled with meat in a spinach sauce). The food and the ambiance made the occasion. If you like to discover special boutique restaurants, and If you're looking for something a little different, you need to look for this place. It is not far from Plaza Mayor (about 7 min walking distance), easy to find and worth the effort. It has reasonable prices and it was a wonderful experience. Highly recommended. I have promised myself that I will return to Madrid just to eat in La Musa Latina again. We were there in Sept.2012.

title_review: The lounge was great for lunch
review_preview: We did not stay in the hotel, so I cannot rate the rooms. The lobby area (which you pass through to get to the lounge), however, is very "chic" and interesting. The staff members were very friendly and  nice. (Not necessarily what you expect when...
review_full: We did not stay in the hotel, so I cannot rate the rooms. The lobby area (which you pass through to get to the lounge), however, is very "chic" and interesting. The staff members were very friendly and nice. (Not necessarily what you expect when you are not at all "hip" in a hip European hotel.) The food in the lounge was innovative/creative/well prepared and the service was excellent. The prices are on the expensive side in general, but less than what you would pay at many of the fancy hotels in the area. In fact, everything about the experience was "excellent" but given that the prices are on the higher side of average I felt compelled to stick with "very good" on my overall rating.

We shared the tomato salad, the Croquetas 2.0, the eggplant hummus, and the charcoal grilled veggies. Everything was fine, but not mindblowing. The veggies also arrived at least 20 minutes after everything else, and we had to remind the servers we had ordered them. With so many other great options nearby that feel more intimate, I probably wouldn't go back.

It is mainly eat at the counter bar style and some dishes are under glass on the counter for you to view.  A local recommended we come here for the foie (which is the proper door medallion, not pate de froies gras) and the tortilla (which was genuinely and so moist with lots of caramelised onion in it) and both were excellent.  Through broken English, our friendly young waiter recommended two of us to share the pork fillets with mustard caramel and it was truly superb, served on a "bed" of thin slices potatoes.  I don't give 5 stars very often but this was a truly scrumptious lunch well served and highly recommended.

title_review: An excellent meal in La Latina
review_preview: Had an amazing dining experience at this place. Was walking through La Latina just shy of the dinner rush, and Txirimiri (which as recommended by a friend) was pretty quiet. But 10 minutes into being seated, the small restaurant started to fill up quickly.Food...
review_full: Had an amazing dining experience at this place. Was walking through La Latina just shy of the dinner rush, and Txirimiri (which as recommended by a friend) was pretty quiet. But 10 minutes into being seated, the small restaurant started to fill up quickly. Food was excellent all around, but standouts were: the veal cheeks (perfectly cooked, and FULL of flavor; quite rich), and a "rabo" dish (oxtail) which was a special of the night. Both dishes went extremely perfectly with our bottle of wine (Muga from the La Rioja region). Service was excellent; there was one main server managing the small room, but she was super efficient! A great place all in all, and if I recall, the food is Basque-influenced (in case that makes it more interesting).

title_review: A great touch of Basque food in Madrid
review_preview: We visited this restaurant based on the recommendation of well-known tourist guide and it was really a good decision. This Basque style restaurant offers familiar atmosphere and very tasty meals. We tried Fajita chicken with grilled vegetables and a touch of curry, mushroom risotto with...
review_full: We visited this restaurant based on the recommendation of well-known tourist guide and it was really a good decision. This Basque style restaurant offers familiar atmosphere and very tasty meals. We tried Fajita chicken with grilled vegetables and a touch of curry, mushroom risotto with foie and Pedro Ximenez and Pintxos tasting hot dish „Classic Txirimiri“ and all those dishes have been great. I would especially recommend to try Pintxos tasting hot dish „Classic Txirimiri“ consisted of omelete with caramelized onions, fillet of beef with with caramelized onions and piquillo peppers, foie iron with fig jam and salt Maldom, Pintxo cod tempura with poached peppers Amatxi style and hamburger „Unai“ tempura with porcini sause. The Txakoli wine was also very good. Moreover the price for all meals and drinks was very reasonable. The staff of the restaurant was good but still there is a space to improve customer approach.

We loved it and would definitely recommend stopping in here for dinner or even just a drink in the Latina neighborhood of Madrid.

title_review: Best food i had in Madrid
review_preview: Went there wanted to try the secreto iberico that everyone was raving about. Turned out wasn’t on the menu. Someone who was eating there at the time recommended the Igueldo pincho. So we had it and OMG it was so good. It was squid on...
review_full: Went there wanted to try the secreto iberico that everyone was raving about. Turned out wasn’t on the menu.  Someone who was eating there at the time recommended the Igueldo pincho. So we had it and OMG it was so good. It was squid on some ham and fish roe. You really have to try it! Only 4.90 euro So we decided to try some more. Ordered the Iberian Pen. 15.5 euro. Very soft and succulent pork on a bed of potatoes and some sweet sour sauce. Deliciouss Then we wanted more! So we ordered the Cheek glaze (said come with orange-but ours had no orange on top) but it was melt in your mouth dish!! This was 5.50 euro We also ordered the hamburger “unai” it’s basically meat burger covered in tempura and some mushroom and pepper cream sauce. This was also delicious and big for the price. We’ve been to a few pinchos and tapas places around barcelona and madrid and I have to say this is one of the top two if not the best.

title_review: Okay food in an expensive outfit
review_preview: We went here as we read about this place in some travel blog. On the inside it is modern and industrial, and the outside terrace is in the middle of a picturesque square. The high tables near the wall (where we were seated) are not...
review_full: We went here as we read about this place in some travel blog. On the inside it is modern and industrial, and the outside terrace is in the middle of a picturesque square. The high tables near the wall (where we were seated) are not made for tall western europeans. A long metal rod was in the place where my knees wanted to be. We were unfortunately not reseated. The menu is not printed in english, only an online version was available. Flavor combinations of the tapas were interesting and new, but didn't always work. The restaurant was severely understaffed this evening, and as a result the service was very very slow. The table was too small for more than three tapas.  I really want to give this place a good review, as it checks all my boxes (different food based on traditional food, modern industrial interior, lots of young people), but the overall experience and the food was simply too disappointing.

review_preview: Our first night in Madrid and after a long day travelling we wanted somewhere locally we could walk to to grab some tapas and a glass of wine - well we lucked out finding La Musa Latina. It was busy, around 10pm, but we managed...
review_full: Our first night in Madrid and after a long day travelling we wanted somewhere locally we could walk to to grab some tapas and a glass of wine - well we lucked out finding La Musa Latina. It was busy, around 10pm, but we managed to get a table outside. The waiter was really helpful pointing out the gluten free tapas and desserts, but I went for the halloumi & water melon salad and it was amazing. Maybe the best salad I've ever had! Going to try and recreate that back home. The others went for the tapas selection and thoroughly enjoyed it. They had a selection for two between three of them and it was plenty of food. Bottle of wine and four very happy tourists! I hope the rest of our trip to Madrid is as lovely as La Musa Latina.

review_preview: We were staying near Santo Domingo, but got lost, then caught up in a protest... So we were 15 minutes late for our 8:15pm booking. This restaurant was still so welcoming! No English menu, but between 3 of us we decided to order the tapas...
review_full: We were staying near Santo Domingo, but got lost, then caught up in a protest... So we were 15 minutes late for our 8:15pm booking. This restaurant was still so welcoming! No English menu, but between 3 of us we decided to order the tapas degustation and 2 extra dishes. The waitress was very helpful in recommending 2 more dishes that sounded lovely- and they were! After 3 weeks of Spanish tapas, the Japanese/Chinese fusion here was a breath of fresh air. Different, like the dumpling enchiladas, but it worked! We also had 3 desserts included in the €30 degustion- great value! Overall, food and service were excellent, but bookings are recommended. Definitely we loved the degustation and the green tomatoes.  Oh, and I loved the bread sushi, unlike the majority of other reviewers.

review_preview: Didn't know what to expect other than what we had read on Trip Advisor. Tried booking through the restaurant's own website but was shown no availability until 23.00. Thankfully booked through Fork and got a booking for 19.00. Arrived at the restaurant and it was...
review_full: Didn't know what to expect other than what we had read on Trip Advisor. Tried booking through the restaurant's own website but was shown no availability until 23.00. Thankfully booked through Fork and got a booking for 19.00. Arrived at the restaurant and it was deserted. Nonetheless, it did not disappoint. The food was excellent. What was particularly pleasing was that the four dishes we ordered came one at a time. The staff waited until we finished one before serving another. This made for a perfect sharing meal and ensured every dish was hot. Particularly liked the tuna and tomatoes and the Mediterranean fried vegetables. House wine was good quality. Cost for two with a couple of glasses each just on 70€. Well worth it for the quality of food. Location very suburban in built up area with good seating outside on the pavement. Would go there again if we were here longer.

review_preview: I LOVE the food here!I was on the lookout for traditional Spanish restaurants and I am delighted to have visited El Neru based on the reviews on TA! I am now in Barcelona, and can't stop thinking about the meal I had in El...
review_full: I LOVE the food here! I was on the lookout for traditional Spanish restaurants and I am delighted to have visited El Neru based on the reviews on TA!  I am now in Barcelona, and can't stop thinking about the meal I had in El Neru. When I arrived at the restaurant at about 1pm, the bar was crowded with local people having their beer and tapas. I had to jostle past them to get to the restaurant which was accessed by a downward flight of stairs which led to a cavernous underground seating area. The walls of the restaurant were filled with photos of people who have eaten there, and I could tell it was an established restaurant which was well-loved by many.  My partner and I ordered a set meal consisting of clams in beans + tuna in tomato sauce, and on top of that, we ordered a beef stew and baked hake (basque style). I loved every dish that came (except the tuna; not because it was not well done, but I realise I'm not a fan of the fish). From the taste, I could tell that a lot of effort has been put into preparing the stock and sauces for the dishes. Each dish was extremely tasty and had depth.  For the dishes, we paid about 60e, very reasonable for the amazing food quality. If you are looking for a traditional restaurant to visit, you MUST visit El Neru. If I'm ever back in Madrid, it will definitely be on my to-eat list.

The slamon sashimi was good, but it was just a nice cut of salmon with sweet mustard, Aoli, and a piece of avocado. The second thing was a noodle dish, I know, I should know better not to order Asian things in Spain but I was really craving a taste of home. Serves me right, it was a fail. The noodle looked like they came out of a ramen packet, the dish was soaked in lots of salt - too sweet and salty. It was all that I could taste.  Now an almost an hour later and still waiting for my third dish... What was all the fuss about this place? I don't see it nor the "modern" spanish tapas?

review_preview: Visited La Musa Latina on Wednesday night with my mum who is visiting me from London, I live a five minute walk from this place and all I can say is that I WISH I had visited SOONER! We were seated inside the lovely air...
review_full: Visited La Musa Latina on Wednesday night with my mum who is visiting me from London, I live a five minute walk from this place and all I can say is that I WISH I had visited SOONER!  We were seated inside the lovely air conditioned restaurant (much preferred this to the terraza), although the service was quite slow, this did not bother me so much as the ambience was really nice! We ordered two beers and five of their imaginative tapas dishes including the guacamole with nacho chips, the mini hamburgers, a box of teriyaki noodles with vegetables, makipan (which included asparagus, steak and cheese) and tempura prawns and avocado! All dishes were outstanding with fantastic presentation.  For dessert, we couldn’t decide so went with the trio of desserts which was the brownie, cheesecake and a cinnamon mouse! – All very tasty! The whole lot cost us 47 euros, which I really don’t think is a lot seeing as we left there completely stuffed and satisfied! I will definitely be visiting again!

review_preview: Found El Neru by chance, just walking by on a street with many attractive restaurants.  (Between Calle Arenal and Calle Mayor, near Plaza Mayor and Puerta del Sol.)  Walk right past the crowded tapas bar downstairs to the charming multi-room restaurant with wood beams and...
review_full: Found El Neru by chance, just walking by on a street with many attractive restaurants. (Between Calle Arenal and Calle Mayor, near Plaza Mayor and Puerta del Sol.) Walk right past the crowded tapas bar downstairs to the charming multi-room restaurant with wood beams and attractive murals. The lunch crowd (2 pm onward in Madrid) is all Spanish speaking and the service was excellent. But the food was what made this an outstanding find. Try the warm alcachofas (artichokes in oil and a touch of garlic) as a first course instead of a salad. The fabada asturiana, an Asturian specialty dish of large beans with a chunk of bacon, a pork sausage and a blood sausage (like a Spanish version of a French cassolet) was excellent as was the solomillo, a thick chunk of sirloin served on a sizzling platter. House wines at €12 a bottle.
