title_review: Excellent for a modern taste of Madrid
review_preview: We went to Musa to celebrate a birthday on a recommendation from a Spanish friend of ours. It's in la Latina, a neighborhood that tourists quite often miss, but is such a quaint historic neighborhood. We ordered pretty much everything on the menu -  the...
review_full: We went to Musa to celebrate a birthday on a recommendation from a Spanish friend of ours. It's in la Latina, a neighborhood that tourists quite often miss, but is such a quaint historic neighborhood.  We ordered pretty much everything on the menu - the croquetas de jamón, potato bombas, pork tataki, and baos were especially good. For dessert we ordered the thousand layer apple pie and the assortment of desserts from the tasting menu, all were very good. For a large meal for 4 people with 2 bottles of wine, it came out to be 110€ which is pretty great for such a high quality meal. Would absolutely go again and recommend to friends.

title_review: One of the three best meals in Madrid.
review_preview: We had two of the three best meals here at La Musa.  The other one at twice the price of La Musa's.  Service was friendly and professional, food was scrumptious, all in a lovely setting.  On our first visit, we ordered their Degustacion - tasting...
review_full: We had two of the three best meals here at La Musa. The other one at twice the price of La Musa's. Service was friendly and professional, food was scrumptious, all in a lovely setting. On our first visit, we ordered their Degustacion - tasting menu - which consisted of 8 tapas dishes (served four at a time), followed by a tasting menu of three little desserts. All fabulous. The menu said 30 euros,which we thought would be 30/pp, so imagine our surprise when the bill arrived and it was 30 euros total! We returned four days later to try some of their other dishes, which were all as scrumptious: tempura langostinos; ramen pancetta; salmon curado; lubina asado; pollo cesar; wok chow-mein; and crumble manzana - YUM! A very satisfying meal, very happy evening!

title_review: DO get out of the taxi and go IN
review_preview: There are several Txirimiri locations in Madrid.  I visited the one on C/Humilladero.  Since I had just arrived in Madrid a few hours before and was totally unfamiliar with the city plan, I decided to take a taxi.   When we got to the neighborhood, I...
review_full: There are several Txirimiri locations in Madrid. I visited the one on C/Humilladero. Since I had just arrived in Madrid a few hours before and was totally unfamiliar with the city plan, I decided to take a taxi. When we got to the neighborhood, I thought "Is this where you will find a great restaurant?" When we reached the front door, I wondered " Do I want to go in?" When I got inside, I wondered "Do I want to eat here?" Well, the answers are yes, yes, and yes. The reason is the food. Taking the server's recommendation, I had atun, a black rice risotto, and a chocolate "cake' (which was more like a truffle). The ambiance isn't great, but the food is what it is all about. Do go ... and do go in.

review_preview: We arrived early for dinner, around 8:30, and we're the first ones in the basement dining room. We ordered a wonderful and reasonably priced bottle of wine. The bread and "cheese" spread were so good we had to pace ourselves so we would have room...
review_full: We arrived early for dinner, around 8:30, and we're the first ones in the basement dining room. We ordered a wonderful and reasonably priced bottle of wine. The bread and "cheese" spread were so good we had to pace ourselves so we would have room for dinner. For a starter, we had fava beans and pork which we devoured. For main courses we had cider baked hake and a leg of lamb. Both which were outstanding. The portions are huge so we didn't get to try dessert. Our waiter brought us a unique digestif liquor which was a perfect ending to the meal.  The dining room was filling up rapidly by the time we finished dinner. The total cost was 75 euros.

review_full: This place is frequented by locals who value excellent service and good ambiance at a very decent price. We found our way to Calle Bordadores after a short stroll from Mercado San Miguel. El Neru was packed, noisy, vibrant and completely charming. We squeezed a place for ourselved at the bar and were immediately offered tortilla, bread and melt-in-your-mouth Andalucian sausage; all of it gratis when you order a couple of small beers!  This is a hidden gem in the Madrid culinary landscape and well worth a visit if you desire something more than the typical tourist eateries along the main avenues.

review_preview: This place was close to our hotel and we walked passed it several times a day.  After discovering it had high ratings on a review app, we decided to give it a whirl.  From the street, it looks really small and crowded.  However, there's a...
review_full: This place was close to our hotel and we walked passed it several times a day. After discovering it had high ratings on a review app, we decided to give it a whirl. From the street, it looks really small and crowded. However, there's a basement restaurant with a ton of tables. We ate down there and it was almost empty (we went on a weekday night, sort of early). Our waiter was attentive and friendly. We had the following: 1. Asparagus - the big white soft kind, not the traditional thin green kind normally eaten in the US 2. Basque Hake Stew - dellicious if you like seafood flavors 3. Beef Stew (on menu something like Choice Beef Cuts) - one of the best dishes I had in Spain, beef stew with some fries thrown on top of it.  4. Some desserts - good but not great I wanted to eat here again just for that beef stew! It isn't a fancy place but it was fun and the food was good.

title_review: Hidden gem with excellent Spanish food
review_preview: Wasn't sure at first as the waiter's didn't speak much English, but luckily they had a bilingual menu. The grilled calamari was amazing!! I ordered the "blocks of beef" (beef cubes that are stewed). The beef was extremely tender and the sauce was wonderful. My...
review_full: Wasn't sure at first as the waiter's didn't speak much English, but luckily they had a bilingual menu. The grilled calamari was amazing!! I ordered the "blocks of beef" (beef cubes that are stewed). The beef was extremely tender and the sauce was wonderful. My husband had the suckling pig and enjoyed it thoroughly. The waiter also gave us a little extra treat with a shot of a yellow liquor which was quite tasty. Prices are very reasonable.

title_review: The best bar in the best city
review_preview: El Ñeru is a small bar/restaurant a short stroll away from the Plaza Mayor. It is bar far my favourite place to go for a snack in Madrid. I have been coming here for years but until now I have selfishly not disclosed its existence...
review_full: El Ñeru is a small bar/restaurant a short stroll away from the Plaza Mayor. It is bar far my favourite place to go for a snack in Madrid. I have been coming here for years but until now I have selfishly not disclosed its existence to anyone else but my best friends. I like it as it is – you seldom see tourists there. The first impression is that it is tiny. Indeed the bar area is very narrow. There is seating at the back. El Ñeru is Asturias transported to Madrid. The favourite tipple here is Asturian cider. If you do not like cider, think again. There is cider and there is Asturian cider. It is wonderful. If you are an Astu-rian you will want to drink your cider the traditional way. This requires great skills, the type of skill that only comes with a great deal of practice. Asturians like to hold the bottle of cider way up over their heads and pour it into a glass held low in the other hand. This is impossible for normal mortals who would invariably miss by a mile. For the Asturian I suspect it is a matter of declaring one’s unique identity. For the outsider it is hugely entertaining to watch them. The object of all of this is to aerate the cider so as to enhance the taste. For less mortals the bar provides a clever little electrically driven dispenser for your cider. You press the button and aerated cider sprays into your glass. Very high tech!  If this wasn’t enough to send you running to visit El Ñeru there is more. If you order anything in the bar it comes with a very generous tapa. You can have chorizo, Asturian blue cheese on bread, or tortilla. If you simply order a glass or cider at €1 and then repeat the order you will soon find that the tapas have left you no room for your dinner. The waiters are terrific. They are efficient and have a great sense of humour. If you leave a tip they clang a cow bell. For more formal eating there is a very Spanish menu. It includes typical Madrid favourites such as tripe. There is a large selection of meat, fish and vegetable dishes. My favourite is fabada Asturiana, Asturian pork and beans. For the quality, I think that the menu is ridiculously cheap. There is also a menu of the day. Please don’t go there when I am visiting. I like to be the only foreigner. Thank you.

title_review: Better for tapas and cider than dining
review_preview: This Asturian restaurant has long been a mainstay in Madrid.  The small upstairs bar area (often packed in the evenings) offers excellent Cabrales cheese tapas and Asturian cider.  The downstairs area is in dire need of refurbishment since it seems to have changed little since...
review_full: This Asturian restaurant has long been a mainstay in Madrid. The small upstairs bar area (often packed in the evenings) offers excellent Cabrales cheese tapas and Asturian cider. The downstairs area is in dire need of refurbishment since it seems to have changed little since the days of Franco. Though the main dishes of the restaurant are good enough - meaning rather heavy - you can find more exciting cuisine in dozens of other similarly priced restaurants throughout Madrid. However, if you are particularly keen on enjoying some authentic Fabada, this is probably your best bet outside of Asturias.

review_preview: I have the pleasure of visiting Madrid at least once a year on business, one of my clients who is originally from Asturias, took me there to taste the fabes con almejas. (Beans with clams)I was overwhelmed!Celebrities have visited that restaurant, it seems...
review_full: I have the pleasure of visiting Madrid at least once a year on business, one of my clients who is originally from Asturias, took me there to taste the fabes con almejas. (Beans with clams) I was overwhelmed! Celebrities have visited that restaurant, it seems to be a tiny little bar at first, but once you go down the old steps you enter an underground culinary paradise. (That is, if you like Spanish food) Even just the white tuna/bell pepper salad was delicious, and they served us sidra in perfect Spanish style. Meaning the waiter had to pour it over his head into a glass in his hand. It's supposed to splash and hit the brim each time it's poured, they did it perfectly and it was delicious. The wine was lovely, service fantastic (especially as my host was a frequent guest). I had a frozen whisky tart for desert which was simply to die for. I dream of going back there, just for that dessert. Granted, it made me tipsy but I didn't regret it in the least. A siesta will clear that up right away. I can highly recommend this place, although reservations should be made as it could get full.

Crusty bread is served with a delicious bleu cheese spread. Very reasonably priced and set in a relaxing atmosphere. review_preview: Having the chance to visit this place made my wife and I happy we missed our connecting flight to Amsterdam! It was a little intimidating at first because our Spanish is fairly poor and it was pretty obvious that this bar was not tailored for...
review_full: Having the chance to visit this place made my wife and I happy we missed our connecting flight to Amsterdam! It was a little intimidating at first because our Spanish is fairly poor and it was pretty obvious that this bar was not tailored for English speaking tourists. However, as soon as we found a place at the bar and ordered our first cerveza and cider (which was accompanied with possibly the best tortilla we've ever had and complimentary with the drinks) we knew we had lucked out in a big way. We were the only English speakers in the crowded little bar, but the waiters were very friendly, and patient enough with our Spanish, that we felt very welcome. I would definitely recommend ordering a glass of cider. They are known for it, and it was unlike any we've had before (in the best way possible). The chipirones were wonderfully flavorful a and delicious as well. I don't know when we'll be in Madrid next, but there is a 100% chance we'll be coming back to El Ñeru when we do.

review_preview: My husband and I happened upon El Neru.  The ground level bar was packed -- so we decided to give it a try.  We were seated in one of the dining rooms downstairs, which was also pretty full.  There was a huge screen TV showing...
review_full: My husband and I happened upon El Neru. The ground level bar was packed -- so we decided to give it a try. We were seated in one of the dining rooms downstairs, which was also pretty full. There was a huge screen TV showing a soccer game with no sound. We enjoyed ourselves very much. The bread comes with a yummy blue cheese spread. We shared a chorizo appetizer, which was delicious. I had the special bean soup and my husband had a very thinly sliced beef filet that was served with a small portion of French fries and a small portion of roasted red peppers. The peppers were cold --- our only complaint about the place. The beef and soup were very good. The house red wine was very good also. Note, as in many restaurants in Madrid, we were charged for the bread...but we were served a complimentary and delicious after dinner 'digestive' drink. This is a good place if you have a large appetite!

review_preview: This place is outstanding. It's owned by a qualified hotelier and someone who has produced an amazing restaurant. It's always very busy so make sure you are prepared to wait for a table.The dining area is typically Spanish, very small & cosy, quaint, very...
review_full: This place is outstanding. It's owned by a qualified hotelier and someone who has produced an amazing restaurant. It's always very busy so make sure you are prepared to wait for a table. The dining area is typically Spanish, very small & cosy, quaint, very little space and packed with people. The place really has a good vibe. The service is typical Spanish as you would get in any tapeteria in Madrid, a very little bit slow but charming. The bar is always packed and you can enjoy a few sparkling wines or beers while waiting for your table. You can even eat at the bar if you wish to. The food is spectacular, reasonably priced and very very well presented. It's fine dining tapas. This place doesn't produce the normal tapas you would get at any tapeteria, he prepares high end tapas and it is exquisite. Dishes such as foie gras on brioche, secreto iberico, outstanding cuts of seared beef and a wide variety of seafoods prepared and produced in a unique fine dining manner, to include a lucsiously rich dark molten chocolate cake. Please note that the menu is in Spanish and the serving staff do not speak English so be prepared. As long as you got a little travel book of food terms, you will generally know what to order. Give it a go, you won't be disappointed. It is so worth it, you just have to go. We were lucky as we had our friends there with us who are Spanish and from Madrid. My favourite was the Secreto Iberico, which I believe is the secret cut of pork from the leg or neck of the Iberian black pig, marinated, seared and served with a dark sauce ... it was the best pork I have ever eaten in my life (apart from wild boar). Well done and keep it up!

review_preview: The concierge at our hotel recommended El Neru as the most authentic Asturiano cuisine in Madrid.  It was one of the best dinners we had on our 10 day trip through Spain.  You enter at street level to a bar and are led downstairs through...
review_full: The concierge at our hotel recommended El Neru as the most authentic Asturiano cuisine in Madrid. It was one of the best dinners we had on our 10 day trip through Spain. You enter at street level to a bar and are led downstairs through a series of small dining rooms. We started with the Empanada Asturia, which is a meat patty; delicious, followed by Fabada Asturia, beans and clams, very traditional and thought to be the best in Spain. We had Triguero asparagus,grown in Asturia, which has an unique flavor and very different from our asparagus; this was cooked a la plancha and exceptionally prepared. Lastly the suckling pig, which was the best we've ever had. the meat fell off the bone and the crackling was crispy, crunchy and perfect. You must go there…..be prepared to sit for 2 hours so that you can fully enjoy the food and order a good bottle of Rioja wine……Traditional food at its best!

review_preview: I've been living in Madrid for 4 years and this is one of my favorite restaurants in Madrid. We come here at least once a month. The workers are very kind and always treat us well. We like to bring family and friends who are...
review_full: I've been living in Madrid for 4 years and this is one of my favorite restaurants in Madrid. We come here at least once a month. The workers are very kind and always treat us well. We like to bring family and friends who are visiting here. The cider is great. Sometimes they will put a pouring machine inside which makes it easier to pour. The cider always comes with a tapa. We usually choose the cabrales cheese or chorizos. The food is spectactular. Some of our favorites are Rabo de toro (oxtail), fabe con almejas (a stew with clams) and cachopo (cured meat fried cutlet with ham and cheese). These are typical dishes from the Asturias area in Northern Spain. We almost always order at the bar. The downstairs is a sit down restaurant if you are looking for something more formal. Don't leave Madrid without going here!

Not being able to see the menu didn’t really help our poor grasp of Spanish (guess it didn’t hurt too much either in our case), so we took our chances with the first item at the top of the pintxo list—a solomillo pintxo. This turned out to be steak, which came out seared medium rare 10-15 minutes later on a piece of toast dressed in a cranberry/cherry and onion sauce. So tender and so juicy…it was like food back at home but better. But this was also our last night in Madrid so it was on to other “must-eat” sites…

review_preview: We chose Cokuy on our last day in Madrid. Mistake. We came for lunch, allured by the menu of the day of 13.95 euros. The paellas (first dish) were just lukewarm and not very tasty. We ordered two steaks "al punto" (medium well) for our...
review_full: We chose Cokuy on our last day in Madrid. Mistake. We came for lunch, allured by the menu of the day of 13.95 euros. The paellas (first dish) were just lukewarm and not very tasty. We ordered two steaks "al punto" (medium well) for our second dish and they were not only overdone, they were also charred and tough to cut. And, to quote Woody Allen, "such small portions." For dessert we ordered the cheesecake, which tasted like sawdust. All three cheesecake slices at our table were obviously semi-frozen, which gave the cake that crumbling sawdust quality, and drenched in a tasteless sauce. In all fairness, the servers were friendly and polite. Still, I wish we had eaten somewhere else to celebrate lovely Madrid and its amazing food. Don't make the mistake we made, please avoid this place!

title_review: El Neru in Madrid Fabada Asturiás
review_preview: Slightly off Plaza Mayor in Madrid Centro but still within walking distance, look for this restaurant! It's a narrow space that looks like just a a bar but down several stairs is the old world style restaurant. I was started with a large crusty but...
review_full: Slightly off Plaza Mayor in Madrid Centro but still within walking distance, look for this restaurant! It's a narrow space that looks like just a a bar but down several stairs is the old world style restaurant. I was started with a large crusty but soft inside bolillo(?) and a spreadable blue cheese-like accompaniment. I ordered delicious sweet cider (like a beer/wine combo, slightly sweet) as I was advised by a local taxi driver to get the Fabada Asturiás which is a Bean Stew. The Bean is native to Asturiás and tastes like a large cannelloni or white kidney bean. It's very satisfying and served with 3 medium pieces of a sausage, a ham/bacon and a dark blood sausage (I found out I don't like blood sausage but I already suspected!). But the wait staff was very kind and helpful to me as a single woman eating alone!

review_preview: I was recommended Triana by the hotel I was staying in and it did not disappoint. The selection of tapas was great and offered something a bit different to the usual tapas selection tourists might immediately go for. The fact this place immediately filled up...
review_full: I was recommended Triana by the hotel I was staying in and it did not disappoint.  The selection of tapas was great and offered something a bit different to the usual tapas selection tourists might immediately go for. The fact this place immediately filled up with locals at 9pm showed it was a popular place....aim to get there a bit before 9 to get a table.  The service was quick and the food was amazing. The grilled octopus with paprika was my favourite dish of the night. They offered an English menu which is helpful, though it's always nice to try and pronounce the dishes in Spanish. Our bill came to about 190euros between four which included about 8 sharing dishes and two bottles of (extremely good) red wine. If you're staying in this area of Madrid, restaurante Triana is worth visiting!

review_preview: Stopped by for the menu del día and was pleasantly surprised to see that it was labeled with allergens. Thinking it was safe, I ordered a shrimp cocktail for my starter, only to receive the entire thing smothered in a yogurt sauce. When we explained...
review_full: Stopped by for the menu del día and was pleasantly surprised to see that it was labeled with allergens. Thinking it was safe, I ordered a shrimp cocktail for my starter, only to receive the entire thing smothered in a yogurt sauce. When we explained to the waiter that the menu indicated that it did not contain dairy, he tried to place the blame back on us. What is the purpose of even having an allergen menu if you don’t abide by it? My boyfriend ordered the vegetables and clarified that the dish was vegetarian. Guess what? It was full of jamón. Still, the waiter tried to divert the blame. We are currently awaiting a new starter for me and our main courses, but I’m not feeling terribly hopeful. Best to avoid.

review_preview: It's sad that this place so be, in our limited experience, so head and shoulders above the rest. It's also one of the few places which -- and maybe some people will disagree -- serves rather more in the English-Spanish style, ie, where you can...
review_full: It's sad that this place so be, in our limited experience, so head and shoulders above the rest. It's also one of the few places which -- and maybe some people will disagree -- serves rather more in the English-Spanish style, ie, where you can have a variety of smaller, less expensive dishes rather than just full-on raciones. I wouldn't say it's amazing, just good -- of the kind of standard that one expects in London. That said there's a simple salad of rocket, warm goat's cheese, skinned, roasted red peppers and toasted walnuts that is excellent, and we enjoyed, too, an avocado salad topped with prawns, though there shouldn't have been any need really to deliver it at 2C, it could have been brought to room temperature, which is always better for avocado. We also enjoyed a potato dish with melted raclette and an aioli, although the English translation of truffles as an accompanied somewhat foxed us, as the little red shavings resembled jamon. The service was very variable; friendly on a Saturday night, completely offhand and rather cold on a Monday. Would go again.

title_review: Fine once you've pushed through the bar
review_preview: Txirimiri has a narrow entrance through a bar with a small, rather plasticky dining-room behind. We arrived at 8.30, preposterously early by Madrid standards, and it was wholly empty. Didn’t bother us; we could pull tables together and make ourselves comfortable. The name of the...
review_full: Txirimiri has a narrow entrance through a bar with a small, rather plasticky dining-room behind. We arrived at 8.30, preposterously early by Madrid standards, and it was wholly empty. Didn’t bother us; we could pull tables together and make ourselves comfortable. The name of the place suggests Basque influence, and the fact that the little starters are called pintxos rather than tapas confirms it. The tortilla was very good, moist inside, a far cry from the rather dry wodges of egg and potato one gets used to. Otherwise we had a couple of plates of bacalao en tempura with caramelised onion, some foie gras, and an odd skewer of what turned out to be fish in a sauce the colour of pale green emulsion. Some of us ate beef ternera, chunks of dark meat in a sherry gravy with potato puree, far more meat than veg, this being Spain, while others had something in the pork line archly called secret iberico. Bottles of Rioja with this. By the time we left the small dining-room had filled and the bar was busy enough for us to have to shove our way through. Crowded; cheerful; indifferent décor. Worth a visit if you're in La Latina. Just about merits four stars; I think the tortilla gets it over the line.

title_review: Excellent and affordable tapas and basque cuisine
review_preview: I've spent lots of time in Madrid in the last years, either for business or leisure, and Txirimiri is definitely one of the first places I'd recommend. The restaurant is very small, and to access it you'll have to pass through the crowd in the...
review_full: I've spent lots of time in Madrid in the last years, either for business or leisure, and Txirimiri is definitely one of the first places I'd recommend. The restaurant is very small, and to access it you'll have to pass through the crowd in the bar and usually wait a bit to be seated. But the food is worth the wait: Basque cuisine at its best in Madrid. My advise, if you go in a group, is to share some tapas to have different tastings, and then go for the wonderful carrillera. There's an excellent choice of Spanish wines too, and the prices are definitely cheap for such quality of food.

title_review: So good we went back twice!
review_preview: I wanted to have "rabo de toro" which is a stew made from ox tail or bull tail.  We went to El Neru with a guide late at night.  We had been trying different tapas bars.  So, even though I was full, I tried the...
review_full: I wanted to have "rabo de toro" which is a stew made from ox tail or bull tail. We went to El Neru with a guide late at night. We had been trying different tapas bars. So, even though I was full, I tried the rabo de toro. A few days later we went back. This time I was hungry and it was even better. It is a rich stew. The meat falls off the bone. The sauce is rich. Our waiter recognized us from our previous visit and was enthusiastic and friendly. I went into the kitchen and told the crew there what a wonderful meal it was--in my fractured Spanish. They were gracious and a bit amused by my performance. My wife had salmon. It was OK.

review_preview: last might some friends took us to have dinner in the Txirimiri located in General Diaz Porlier. We were the only people in the restaurant and no one else came in after we arrived. Our friends had been on numerous occasions and were surprised at...
review_full: last might some friends took us to have dinner in the Txirimiri located in General Diaz Porlier. We were the only people in the restaurant and no one else came in after we arrived. Our friends had been on numerous occasions and were surprised at the poor quality of the food. None of the dishes we ordered were any good at all, and seemed to have the same flavour,, as if they had used the same base as a sauce. both the black lasagne and the meat was served on mashed potato made from a packet. The meat dish (carrillera), which my friends usually raved about was tough, unlike any other time they had had it there. The mango and smoked fish salad was laden with mayonnaise and another sauce that had used on the risotto with cuttlefish, which was very poor. They told the waitress to tell the cook they were dissatisfied but she made no comment and in fact took on a rather surly attitude from then on. Eventually one of my friends asked to see the cook and we discovered that she was not Basque but from Eastern Europe. She was haughty and told us that everything was perfectly fine and that obviously if we had eaten it there couldn't be much to complain about. The truth is that we ate the food because we were all starving after a long day's work and couldn't face leaving and looking for somewhere else. After hearing what she had to say, we cancelled the dessert order and paid without leaving a tip. I would strongly advise you to keep away from this place.

review_preview: I had a meeting in calle fuencarral early one afternoon so I looked for a place to have lunch before. The place had a nice cosy atmosphere and it really looked like a family-owned business. You could have lunch at some tables or at the...
review_full: I had a meeting in calle fuencarral early one afternoon so I looked for a place to have lunch before.  The place had a nice cosy atmosphere and it really looked like a family-owned business. You could have lunch at some tables or at the counter. Because I was alone I opted for the counter. Plates and cutlery are already set and you just sit in. They offer a mostly typical Spanish menu with two dishes, one drink, bread and dessert for around 10€.  The food was quite average. I had the risotto and tuna with tomato sauce.  You can tell the dishes are not only cooked but already plated by the almost no time it takes to order and get served (best part about the place). I didn't know that, otherwise I would have never ordered a risotto, obviously...  The tomato sauce with the tuna was quite sweet and the tuna was definitely not fresh (frozen perhaps, or just overcooked...).  Apparently they are really good on desserts but I had too much sweet with the tomato sauce so I went for the coffee.  I had read a couple of reviews and was expecting a nice little place (which it was) where you could have some home cooked meals but I was a bit (very...) disappointed with the food.  I guess around Fuencarral you can find better value for your money. But if you are in a hurry this might be the best option (I'm quite sure they must be faster than some fast food places).

review_preview: Went here with 7 friends. Although we didn't have a reservation, the restaurant was kind enough to seat us within 20 minutes. They have a reasonable gin-tonic selection if you're into that. As for the food: we took the 2-person tasting menu, x3 that is....
review_full: Went here with 7 friends. Although we didn't have a reservation, the restaurant was kind enough to seat us within 20 minutes. They have a reasonable gin-tonic selection if you're into that. As for the food: we took the 2-person tasting menu, x3 that is. They serve it to share, as usual in Madrid, and basically it's like tapas, but not the usual albondigas, patatas bravas, calamares and what not. We ate carilleros, which was so good we ordered a bit more, as goes for the bomba de patata. Other stuff was also very good. The postres/dessert consisted of a selection of chocolate-caramel cake, cheesecake and a vanilla-strawberry cream, lovely. Would definitely recommend going here!

review_preview: If you like fabada, this is a must try restaurant. The place is half a block from Calle Mayor as you walk down towards Arenal on the left side of the street. Anything you order will satisfy your palate but their fabada is as genuine...
review_full: If you like fabada, this is a must try restaurant. The place is half a block from Calle Mayor as you walk down towards Arenal on the left side of the street. Anything you order will satisfy your palate but their fabada is as genuine as it gets. Make sure you wash it down with some sidra. Personally I like both types, the sweet and the dry and feel either one will go with a good fabada although the dry one is perhaps more appropriate because it tends to have a lighter flavor to conbtrast with the heaviness of the dish. You don't have to sit down and have a meal in order to enjoy el Neru. The upstairs bar is narrow and has an even narrower counter on the other side of the bar so you can have something to drink with your racion de fabada....a great tapa. This is one of my stops every time I visit Madrid for food from Asturias. Prices are acceptable and the service friendly and professional. You will not be dissapointed.

review_preview: I have just seen that another group had problems with gluten free options at this restaurant .We had a good experience despite us speaking little Spanish and the waiter very little English. .The waiter pointed out what was safe to eat. We had gluten free...
review_full: I have just seen that another group had problems with gluten free options at this restaurant .We had a good experience despite us speaking little Spanish and the waiter very little English. .The waiter pointed out what was safe to eat. We had gluten free bread and ordered a gluten free beer. We even had squid in a gluten free batter . The waiter we had could not have been more helpful but it was early in the evening and we were the first people in the dining area. We also had a feel for what would be gluten free on the menu so stuck to asking about those dishes . It is a shame that the other group found their waiter so unhelpful . I would advise anyone trying this restaurant to have some knowledge of Spanish as it was not always easy to communicate and the GF food is not as easy to identify as the restaurant front window suggests .Also it is not open on Monday or Tuesday evenings in July. If you are a newly diagnosed coeliac and not yet fully sure of what to avoid and what foods may present a risk I probably would advise you not visit this place .

review_preview: Four of us arrived at 9:30pm and were seated immediately. We opted for two of the €30 degustation menu (recommended for 2 people) between four of us. We also ordered drinks. The first 4 dishes (cold tapas) came out quickly and we ate them. 20...
review_full: Four of us arrived at 9:30pm and were seated immediately. We opted for two of the €30 degustation menu (recommended for 2 people) between four of us. We also ordered drinks. The first 4 dishes (cold tapas) came out quickly and we ate them. 20 minutes after we finished eating then though, we hadn't been checked on and our plates hadn't been cleared. We finally got the attention of our waitor and he gestured at us "I'll be right there". Another 5-10 minutes and he cleared our plates. 15 minutes later the four hot tapas arrived. We ate them and by this stage we were getting very peeved with the lack of service. A waitor tried to take a half-full smoothie from our table but our waitor didn't come to clear our plates for another 15 minutes after we finished. As soon as he cleared the plates, we asked for the dessert tapas and the bill to come at the same time. The desserts finally arrived but the bill didn't. We got the bill and went up to pay because we couldn't be bothered to wait (they do split bills which is a positive). A dinner of tapas took 2 hours. I understand that service is Europe is slower and more relaxed but this was ridiculous. It was a Thursday night and whilst the restaurant was buzzing, it definitely wasn't too busy. The only thing that managed to redeem them was the food and reasonable price of drinks. Food was great and so was the sangria. We left very full from the tasting menu, and €30 each for a meal including dessert is great However if you are looking for good service and a normal-length dinner, go elsewhere. I don't like being ignored in a restaurant and we basically were.

I'd say the only good thing about this place is the lovely tilework on the walls! Do not go here if you need to stay gluten-free!

title_review: Great food let down by slow service
review_preview: We've been here a few times before, yesterday afternoon we met a friend for a few drinks and lunch. We were unable to get a table outside or upstairs so were directed downstairs where the one waiter serving seemed completely overwhelmed. The restaurant seems to...
review_full: We've been here a few times before, yesterday afternoon we met a friend for a few drinks and lunch. We were unable to get a table outside or upstairs so were directed downstairs where the one waiter serving seemed completely overwhelmed. The restaurant seems to be getting more and more popular with the tourists which has severely compromised the service as they don't appear to have hired additional support.  We felt let down by the length of time it took to get a drink and to be served and the lack of attention given by the waiter - we'd have easily drunk and eaten more had he been more attentive. We'll still go again but it's nicer when it's quieter and seems to be losing qualities as it becomes more popular.

review_preview: Everything on this vegetarian restaurant menu sounds appetising. We could have chosen any of the salads or dishes and I'm sure we wouldn't have been disappointed. In addition, off-menu there are the 'day's dishes': two different pastas, one quiche and a special. All patiently and...
review_full: Everything on this vegetarian restaurant menu sounds appetising. We could have chosen any of the salads or dishes and I'm sure we wouldn't have been disappointed. In addition, off-menu there are the 'day's dishes': two different pastas, one quiche and a special. All patiently and interestingly explained. I changed my mind several times. In the end we shared two sorts of vegetarian paté - dried tomato and aubergine- as a starter. They were more like dips, accompanied by bread sticks and thin slices of carrot and celery. As main courses we had the vegetable couscous and 'pastel de maiz', a type of corn pudding done in the oven with a cheese coating (the day´s special). The desserts are all tempting and homemade. Jugs of water are served American-style as you sit down. The wines are simple and reasonably priced. There's also organic beer.... We were impressed. Must book at weekends like everywhere good in Madrid.

review_preview: We were fortunate to get a table for 7 at midday during the week as this is a restaurant frequented by professional workers in the area. We chose the Menú del Día which was a bit more expensive than other restaurants nearby. Our experience was...
review_full: We were fortunate to get a table for 7 at midday during the week as this is a restaurant frequented by professional workers in the area. We chose the Menú del Día which was a bit more expensive than other restaurants nearby. Our experience was not that of having tapas or the ham for which the Cinco Jotas is known, but the Menú. Service was very efficient and attentive. Portions, although not huge, were fine, and the different plates were presented in a beautifully modern way. The dishes had a slight zing of brightness to them which made the dining experience different from most of the traditional Spanish restaurants where we had previously eaten. I especially remember the salad that I selected from the Menú. The strong balsamic vinegar laced along the rim of the bowl allowed the diner to bring it into the greens. We were pleased with our meals and would recommend the restaurant to others.

review_full: I love how everything here is so simple. You order what you want (you can see most of the things on the bar), enjoy the meal, if you speak Spanish you can chat with the cute granny, Mary, pay and leave.  Orange juice is fresh, you can see the granny squeeze the juice from fresh oranges, coffee is ok (I like the milk coffee), tortillas are exquisite, churros are really good too. Churros are as good as Ginés, however the hot chocolate is better at Ginés (but also more expensive). You can ask the granny for some milk to add into the hot chocolate if you think it is too thick/heavy and turn it into a milk chocolate! Fees are not high! I truly recommend this place for a breakfast!

review_preview: We wanted to try something special in Madrid. Found this local taberna on Tripadvisor and as it was located not far away from our hotel, we thought to give a try. It is a very small place, a few tables and chairs. The table reservation...
review_full: We wanted to try something special in Madrid. Found this local taberna on Tripadvisor and as it was located not far away from our hotel, we thought to give a try. It is a very small place, a few tables and chairs. The table reservation is strongly recommended as it gets really busy at evening times and people stand outside waiting for their free tables. The food was delicious but what makes this taberna a star is the customer service.The waiters are flying around the place, speak english and are very helpful. We got a nice sweet treat at the end. The prices are very cheap. If you want to avoid of touristic restaurants and have good tapas with a nice local spanish wine, this is a place to go.

review_preview: Remember, Europeans still smoke around restaurants.  Local places pride themselves on their ham products.  Some of the local hams can go for $195 per kilo. Cinco Jotas has a large display of aged pig legs behind the main counter.  They also carved a pig leg...
review_full: Remember, Europeans still smoke around restaurants. Local places pride themselves on their ham products. Some of the local hams can go for $195 per kilo. Cinco Jotas has a large display of aged pig legs behind the main counter. They also carved a pig leg beside our table. The first course was plates of 2 different types of sliced ham served cold with a baked flat bread. They were all good. Next we were served bread with a tomato sauce spread on it, gazpacho style soup, large white cold asparagus, croquettes made with chicken and white fish and an Spanish omelet. Dessert consisted of cheesecake and lemon sorbet. The food was great and the waiters were all over the place helping with every detail. The outside area tables were right by the front door. Every time the doors were opened, smoke from the smokers at the tables drifted inside.

title_review: Good but not not enough to be in Madrid's top10
review_preview: My friends and I decided to visit La Gaditana to experience a real Spanish Taberna. Pros:- Restaurant is huge - we managed to find a table for 8 ppl. on a Saturday night without reservation- Waitress was very friendly- Very affordable-...
review_full: My friends and I decided to visit La Gaditana to experience a real Spanish Taberna.  Pros: - Restaurant is huge - we managed to find a table for 8 ppl. on a Saturday night without reservation - Waitress was very friendly - Very affordable - Menu was authentic - no unnecessary tries to be international / contemporary - Portions - huge Cons: - Quality of the food - I was very disappointed by the quality of the food. In my opinion part of it was frozen (e.g. shrimps) because they were tasteless and their meat was sandy. Tuna was too salty, probably because it was preserved in a salty marinade instead of being fresh. Don't get me wrong; i have eaten MUCH worst, and probably the quality is fair when looking at the price. This being said, I would have expected much better quality from a Tripadvisor top place. - (Small Con)Restaurant is huge - You feel a bit like a number

review_preview: Well out of the main centre but well worth the taxi ride. There are 2 establishments; Taberna, just a tapas bar and the main restaurant, with outfront tapas bas. Service is very friendly and efficient and the food good quality tapas into full meals. We...
review_full: Well out of the main centre but well worth the taxi ride. There are 2 establishments; Taberna, just a tapas bar and the main restaurant, with outfront tapas bas. Service is very friendly and efficient and the food good quality tapas into full meals. We booked for just one evening but went again and would highly recommend the experience. The groundfloor tapas bar gets full quickly and pushing ones way to the restaurant area at the back is part of the fun; why not stop for an aperitif but be carefull not to eat too much, save space for the main event. The seafood and meat carpaccios are outstanding; a great wine list at reasonable prices. Make certain you have written directions &/or map as many taxi drivers seem confused that far out (only 5 or 6 Euros from centre).

title_review: The best seafood at incredible prices
review_preview: My family and I had been looking for a replacement for another seafood taberna in Madrid which closed. We found it at La Gaditana and we are very happy once again. We really prefer the traditional small bar/restaurants that you can find in Spain over...
review_full: My family and I had been looking for a replacement for another seafood taberna in Madrid which closed. We found it at La Gaditana and we are very happy once again. We really prefer the traditional small bar/restaurants that you can find in Spain over the new style tapas types of restaurants. La Gadatina is a true gem for Spaniards and tourists alike who know what fine dining is supposed to be about: Quality food at reasonable prices with friendly smiles and helpful tips.  We ate here with my kids and their mother late one night for our first memorable occasion when we found a couple of square feet of unoccupied space between the bar and the back room door. The place was packed wall to wall for a birthday party and everyone had a blast. I went back again with the kids for a little snack which turned out to be a full course meal once again. It is such an incredible pleasure to have to fight with my 6 year old daughter and 12 year old son over who gets to eat more chopitos (do not confuse this with chupitos... I was offered a chupito after eating all the chopitos), fried shark, crunchy shrimp pancakes, croquetas de jamon and calamari. The fried eggplant slivers we also a real treat. That is right... my kids appetites at this restaurant attest to the quality of the fare. I wont say anything about the deserts except "wow"... I hope you get an idea from the photos. Thank you La Gaditana and see you this summer! Stop by and try this place out... you can't go wrong!

title_review: A good restaurant in the Salamanca area of Madrid
review_preview: Went for a family Sunday lunch.  We hadn’t booked but a table was found on the 2nd floor. There is a lift which was useful as we a child in a pushchair with us.  Toilets are in the basement.  The food was well prepared and...
review_full: Went for a family Sunday lunch. We hadn’t booked but a table was found on the 2nd floor. There is a lift which was useful as we a child in a pushchair with us. Toilets are in the basement. The food was well prepared and good quality. A lasagne made with pork cheek meat was particularly nice also a chocolate fondant pudding. Prices in line with other mid range restaurants with mains from 15 euros up to about 30 euros. We wanted a Rueda Verdejo wine and the waiter pointed us towards a cheaper rather than more expensive type. We appreciated that and the wine was very nice. All in all a very good experience in a relaxing atmosphere in a busy restaurant. If eating in that area of the city again we would go back

review_preview: On a lovely and very warm for September, Monday, we were shopping in Salamanca and at some point we wanted to have lunch, preferably outdoors to enjoy one of the finest days of late September.Madrid was wonderful, and we were walking in all the...
review_full: On a lovely and very warm for September, Monday, we were shopping in Salamanca and at some point we wanted to have lunch, preferably outdoors to enjoy one of the finest days of late September. Madrid was wonderful, and we were walking in all the beautiful streets and we found ourselves in the 2 very beautiful cul de sacs near Calle Jorge Juan. They were around 5 very pretty and inviting restaurants next to each other with beautiful table settings and elegant Madrilenos eating drinking and enjoying the amazing weather. We found the best possible sun trap on a corner table at the Cinco Jotas. They welcomed us in a cool and warm way, and they brought us the menu and some nibbles. We chose an Ensalada Rusa, the stone cooked beef steak for 2 persons a simple tomato and garlic salad and a bottle of red wine. Everything was lovely but when The meat arrived we could not believe what we were tasting. The most tender and soft and juicy and tasty meat ever! The meat was half cooked on the stone and continued cooking in front of us, served with French fries, coarse sea salt and mustard. I have no words to describe the delicious taste of the meat. Congratulations to the people behind the Cinco Jotas. On my next visit to Madrid I will definitely return to enjoy another meal.

Best meal of our holiday so far.  Pricing was reasonable at under €70.

title_review: Excellent local tapas, with no tourists around....
review_preview: We found this place by a recommendation of a young man in the street and I must say it was an excellent find. We were 5 people from our team, who wanted to eat like the locals do, which is not so easy to find...
review_full: We found this place by a recommendation of a young man in the street and I must say it was an excellent find. We were 5 people from our team, who wanted to eat like the locals do, which is not so easy to find in the center of a big city... This place offered a very good and quick service, we tried many different tapas together and they were all great; Good choice for vegetarians, good red wine from the open bottle, great seafood, the only downturn was a forgotten beer, that was then pulled very fast and not well. Apart from that we did not see any tourists, which we found a great plus, the place is decorated in the very local style and is a bit darkish, so you must like this. The price we paid was really worth it, so if you are looking for a tapas dinner the way the local spend their evening, this is definitely a place to consider. We thought the service/ price ratio was excellent.

title_review: Nice little restaurant with great jamón ibérico
review_preview: This is a small restaurant in a passage off Jorge Juan street. It's part of a chain which owns five restaurants under the same name in Madrid and Barcelona. I've tried the one in Rambla Catalunya in Barcelona, which was quite good, but the Jorge...
review_full: This is a small restaurant in a passage off Jorge Juan street. It's part of a chain which owns five restaurants under the same name in Madrid and Barcelona. I've tried the one in Rambla Catalunya in Barcelona, which was quite good, but the Jorge Juan restaurant was a better experience for some reason. The jamón ibérico was of superior quality in both, but I found the Barcelona branch was more of a tapas place (and very good at that, too), in a modern setting, whereas Jorge Juan has more of a bistro feel, with a cozier setting. Both have the same meat dishes, as well as the types of Spanish hams. At Cinco Jotas Jorge Juan I had the best Huevos Estrellados I've tried anywhere, and I also recommend their "sopa de frutas" desert.

title_review: Probably the best pizza in Madrid!
review_preview: Located in a somewhat shady area, this place looks very basic but wow, they sure know how to make pizza! Lopez & Lopez is my son’s favorite place for pizza (he lives in Madrid).  The pizza has a thin crust - I’m not sure if...
review_full: Located in a somewhat shady area, this place looks very basic but wow, they sure know how to make pizza! Lopez & Lopez is my son’s favorite place for pizza (he lives in Madrid).  The pizza has a thin crust - I’m not sure if the oven is wood fired but at least the pizza tastes like that! I chose filling with serrano ham & rocket – magic! My husband chose four cheeses with truffle oil – also magic if not even better than mine! My son favorite is pepperoni (salami sausage) with mozzarella – to die for! The red house wine is Italian – also very tasty!  A pizza costs approx. 12 EURO each, a bottle of red wine approx 15 EURO.

title_review: Pleasant ambience, good food specializing in jamon iberico
review_preview: We arrived as a party of three without a reservation mid-week around 21:00 or so and were seated quickly on the third level of this three-tier restaurant, as most of the tables were occupied on the first two levels.  With its glass front and ceiling,...
review_full: We arrived as a party of three without a reservation mid-week around 21:00 or so and were seated quickly on the third level of this three-tier restaurant, as most of the tables were occupied on the first two levels. With its glass front and ceiling, and its wooden panels and floors, and spacious proportions, the restaurant has a bright airy feel to it. The low-volume jazz playing in the background enhanced the calm and relaxed atmosphere of the place. The restaurant is part of a chain designed to promote the brand Cinco Jotas jamon iberico, from the black pig which is indigenous to the Spanish south-west and that feeds principally on acorns for its diet. The plate of jamon we shared as an appetizer was outstanding. For main dishes, two of us had the tataki de presa, a pork filet very lightly braised on the outside and pink on the inside. Very tender and juicy. The third person in our party had a steak, which was also done perfectly. The accompanying vegetables were appropriately done but nothing inspiring. We didn't stay for desserts or coffees. Service was quick, efficient and friendly.

review_preview: We went out for dinner at 7 which is not at all the normal dining time for Spanish people. Since the "normal" restaurants were still closed we ended up in Cinco Jotas as their first guests. Although a chain, the ambience was nice and we...

The only downer was the Ribera del Duero which was no good!

review_preview: Off the main road in a mews-like place we had wonderful lunch dishes, especially the croquettes with a special filling, a plate of mixed vegetables, a plate of fried eggs topped by thinly sliced  Iberico ham   with chips, goog rioja wine, tasty olives, fresh baguette,...
review_full: Off the main road in a mews-like place we had wonderful lunch dishes, especially the croquettes with a special filling, a plate of mixed vegetables, a plate of fried eggs topped by thinly sliced Iberico ham with chips, goog rioja wine, tasty olives, fresh baguette, and a pleasant talk with the who explained the retaurant',s name. It might sound simplest cooking, but it was only lunch and transmitted the feeling of the real Spain at € 51 for two sharing 3 dishes plus coffees. We will come back for dinner which, unfortunately starts after 9 pm, which we find a bit late, but is the custom of Spain. Generally speaking we found the Salamanca district of Madrid the most satisfying place if you look for restaurants that, even if a little more expensive, do not disappoint you.

We also built up a bit of an appetite on the walk there, so it would have been rude not to try some of the food too! We had the sea urchins, chorizo in cider, and the penca (which is crab meat with spinach) and all 3 I would happily recommend. title_review: Still dreaming about the goat cheese starter!
review_preview: We only had 24 hours in Madrid and thankfully we stayed at a friend's flat in this neighborhood. He suggested Couzapin and it was awesome!!! This was our last stop in Europe and also happened to be our anniversary. For starters, try the local cider,...
review_full: We only had 24 hours in Madrid and thankfully we stayed at a friend's flat in this neighborhood. He suggested Couzapin and it was awesome!!! This was our last stop in Europe and also happened to be our anniversary. For starters, try the local cider, it's an experience you won't want to miss (a bucket, on the ground to catch overflow, is involved :-). I ordered the goat cheese salad as a starter and I'm still dreaming about it, I have no idea how they managed to "encrust" it similar to creme brûlée. SO delicious! I ordered the fish of the day and my husband had the steak, both were out-of-this world amazing!! Despite the language barrier (our limited Spanish and their limited English) we managed to order everything we wanted. The staff were so friendly and welcoming, amazing service, amazing wine, spirits and food. If ordering dessert, try their house cordial (kind-of like Bailey's liquor only WAY better)!!! I highly recommend this little gem of a restaurant in the heart of Madrid!!

review_preview: I was in Madrid last weekend and decided to have lunch at Ten con Ten at the last minute. I called and was able to get a table easily (a positive part of Covid). I was a little bit skeptical but left with an excellent...
review_full: I was in Madrid last weekend and decided to have lunch at Ten con Ten at the last minute. I called and was able to get a table easily (a positive part of Covid). I was a little bit skeptical but left with an excellent impression. The restaurant is quite big with different dining rooms (all of them are charming). I love the blue decor and everything was beautifully set. I was hesitating as between the Pedreiro Roasted Octopus and the razor clams as a starter and the waitress kindly offered me to have a half-portion of each (though it was not indicated in the menu). That was a great suggestion. The razor clams were a pure delight. I then had the candied suckling pig with mashed apple and this was really delicious and the portion generous. After this, I was full but still wanted some sweets to end up my lunch and I opted for a passion fruit sorbet, which was an excellent choice. The service was very professional, the staff was friendly and attentive to the clientele.They have great Laguiole knives which is a sign of very good quality. It's not cheap but the quality is there so I was very happy and will come back next time I go to Madrid.

title_review: Good food but service was too much room for improvement
review_preview: Went in with a large group for weekday dinner. Ordered several dishes which ranged from good to very good. Lomo de Buey was very good with a lovely and intense wooden scent. Price was a bit off charts especially taking into account that all the...
review_full: Went in with a large group for weekday dinner.   Ordered several dishes which ranged from good to very good. Lomo de Buey was very good with a lovely and intense wooden scent. Price was a bit off charts especially taking into account that all the main dishes costed about the same and some were fulfilling while others were very small (the Rabo de Toro dish is basically a 27€ tapa). Food itself was a 4/5. Desert was quite overpriced. Cheesecake tasted really artificial. Service was inattentive. They were somewhat clumsy and failed to refilled our drinks too often. Some orders were just ignored and they never offered anything proactively. One waiter in particular was somewhat smelly. This will keep us from coming back anytime soon.

Didn’t want to make a fuss since our friends are locals and although we have found any rice dishes here in Spain tend to be saltier anyway but this fried rice was pretty salty. Not sure what is the fuss about since the food was good but definitely not so good that we would be back. We have found many other restaurants in the city to be much more relaxing where no one rushes in fact the opposite and the food very very good for half the price. For the rush and the price, nay.

review_preview: Monty's is excellent!My wife and I found Monty's here on trip advisor... It was a bit out of our way, but we're glad we made the trek.Mi español no es bueno, but with the help of our waiter (and Google Translate) we made...
review_full: Monty's is excellent! My wife and I found Monty's here on trip advisor... It was a bit out of our way, but we're glad we made the trek. Mi español no es bueno, but with the help of our waiter (and Google Translate) we made it work.  This is easily 2 steps above bar tapas. We ordered these delicious fried goat cheese balls to start. Fantastic! (They served us 5, I ate the first one before I thought to take pictures. Lo siento!) Our mojitos were delicious. I ordered the Argentinian steak with truffled mashed potatoes. My wife had the pulled pork burger (our waiter, Manuel, used his limited English to make sure we understood this was pork not beef. Very helpful!) The pulled pork had some delicious fried queso and a side of fries (chips to ye Brits) Those of you who know me know that I am a steak lover. This steak was probably in the top 5 of my life. A beautiful piece of hanger steak, perfectly salted, you can taste the smoke from the grill. And the chef hit a proper medium. Brilliant. The prices were extremely reasonable for what we were served. Steak was under 10 Euros. In Massachusetts, that's a $25 plate all day long. Our whole bill, 2 drinks, an appetizer and 2 meals was less than 40 Euros.  At the end of the meal, we managed to put together enough Spanish to ask for a cab. Another waiter came over, and explained in perfect English how we could catch one on the street, what the green light means, etc.  Our experience at Monty's was a solid 5 stars! Cinco estrellas! Perfecto!

Since it was raining and cold, we decided to leave and come back for something warm. The menu of the day is a good deal. We enjoyed the warm soup with noodles, the rissotto with mushrooms and ham was delicious and the cocida (mixed meat dish with potatoes and carrots) was ok. Table service by the young woman was fine. They lose 1 point for false advertising on their website and 1 point for actually turning us away instead of trying to work something out for us. The food itself was a 4.5 overall.

title_review: Very average place - so many far superior places in Madrid...
review_preview: Pedro Larumbe is supposed to be a renowned Spanish chef. Having been to his restaurant 3 times in 4 days for breakfast, lunch and dinner, I really do not know how.Decor is... non-existent. Feels like a hospital canteen with nicer tables. Ambience would be...
review_full: Pedro Larumbe is supposed to be a renowned Spanish chef. Having been to his restaurant 3 times in 4 days for breakfast, lunch and dinner, I really do not know how. Decor is... non-existent. Feels like a hospital canteen with nicer tables.  Ambience would be best described as stiff.  There is virtually no choice for breakfast. Bread or toast. Service was good. Lunch was OK. Not offensive, not amazing. Service was good. We had a company dinner there on our last night in Madrid. Food was lovely (not amazing), the staff were quite rude. They took one of my starters and my main, both unfinished, without asking whether I was done (I wasn't). At the end they refused to bring more wine to the table, said we had to go to a crappy room at the back where they were showing the champions league if we wanted more drinks. They said they were closing the restaurant. We went for a drink next door after the match finished and when walking past Larumbe on our way to the taxi rank 1.5hrs later, there were four people still sitting at a table chatting away - and having drinks. Genuinely don't know how the fuss is about. Madrid is packed with amazing restaurants. El 38 de Larumbe definitely would not be one of them.

review_preview: My good friend who lives in Madrid loves this place. After several days of Spanish cuisine we opted for Italian and it turned out excellent.The restaurant is really cute, cosy and full of character. We were warmly greeted and seated. Once our drinks were...
review_full: My good friend who lives in Madrid loves this place. After several days of Spanish cuisine we opted for Italian and it turned out excellent. The restaurant is really cute, cosy and full of character. We were warmly greeted and seated. Once our drinks were ordered, we took our time going over the menu, which was not too large or limited, just right. For starters, we opted for baked mozzarella in pomodoro, tuna salad and beef carpaccio. Everything was fantastic. The carpaccio was the best I have EVER had in my life. Excellent quality paper thin beef with a gorgeous full flavoured dressing. Delightful. For mains we had pasta with seafood, spaghetti carbonara, spaghetti arrabiata and ravioli (forgot the filling). The pastas were really very good, delicately prepared and presented and full of fresh flavours. The seafood pasta was really very good and contained an excellen selection of seafood in a fresh tomato sauce, yum. Service was very good, warm and friendly and the entire experience was perfect for the group of friends... A definite must visit if you're looking for home country Italian cooking.

We had a brownie on our last day - we ordered one but were given two (unsure if this was an accident but it was absolutely appreciated!) and it was so good - so rich and fudgy. We need somewhere like this in the UK!
